Z. Nurjamal leads the group. She is 35 years old and has three children. Her husband provides for the family by doing odd jobs. Nurjamal helps her husband by raising cattle and selling milk. She sees herself as his right hand and assistant in providing for their children. She also believes that her business has a big future, but needs time and financial support, and has applied for a loan to buy some goats. 

Nurjamal’s partners in this loan group are:

K. Akylai, 40, who is married and has five children. Her husband is a shepherd, and together they raise livestock and farm. They will use their portion of this loan to work their field. 

A. Erkayim, 37, is divorced and has a four-year-old son. She makes a living raising livestock which she inherited from her parents. She has a stable income of $140 a month and hopes to use this loan to buy some sheep. 

T. Mubarahan, 47, is married and has five children. Her husband works as a guard in a local school while she raises livestock, sells milk and farms a piece of land. She needs a loan to buy fuel to use to work in her field.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and watch a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, which is called Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to help four people expand their small businesses

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Djiguiya (4femmes mariées  et 1 célibataire) avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, ont en moyenne  5 enfants et vivent  dans des  familles polygames à Ouayerma II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les prêts passés se sont  bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de produits alimentaires tels la pomme de terre avec Maïmouna C., le bois de  chauffe,les vêtements pour  enfants.etc.
Maïmouna compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter,  10 sacs de 100kg de pomme de terre, au grand marché du quartier Médine et dans les vergers des villages avoisinants.  Elle les revend au  marché de Ouayerma II et en famille, à une clientèle composée  d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Djiguiya group (four married women and one single woman), average 30 years of age, have five children each on average and live in polygamous families in Ouayerma II, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their seventh loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, which which they aim to be able to satisfy the needs of their customers; all their past loans have been fully repaid. This group of women buy and sell food products, such as potatoes (as is the case for Maïmouna C.), firewood, children's clothes etc. Maïmouna is planning to use her loan to buy ten 100kg sacks of potatoes at the large market in the Médine district and in the orchards in surrounding villages. She resells them at the market in Ouayerma II and within the family, to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and often on credit. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 35,000FCFA, of which part will be used for household expenses and the rest invested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase potatoes

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Horonya est constitué de  huit  femmes (six mariées, une veuve et une célibataire) ayant en moyenne  28 ans, 2 enfants et habitant à Sanoubougou I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de pouvoir mener des activités génératrices de revenus. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que les pagnes avec Nana Kadidia C., le bois de chauffe, les produits de beauté, la friperie et les boissons.
Nana Kadidia C. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 20 colis de pagnes.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de Sikasso et au Burkina Faso (un pays voisin). Les pagnes sont vendus au  marché  Sanoubougou I et  à l’intérieur du quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Horonya group is made up of eight women (six married, one widow and one single). They are on average 28 years old with two children and live in Sanoubougou I, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). This is their first collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to practice income-generating activities. This group of women sells various articles such as “pagnes” [traditional colorful wraparound fabric] as is the case for Nana Kadidia C.. They also sell firewood, beauty products, second hand clothing and beverages. Nana Kadidia C. wants to use her loan to buy 20 packages of “pagnes”. She gets her supply at the large Sikasso market and in Burkina Faso (a neighboring country). The “pagnes” are sold at the Sanoubougou I market and inside the neighborhood to a customer base of women and men, for cash and often on credit. She plans to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 Franc CFA. . One part will be used for the family’s expenses and the other will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Jantoyerela Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Jantoyerela sont  des femmes mariées  avec en moyenne 38 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  des produits alimentaires  tels les fruits et légumes avec Mariam C., les poissons, les tubercules et la restauration.
Mariam C. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  10 paniers de fruits (avocats). Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et dans  les villages avoisinants auprès des producteurs.  Les fruits sont vendus au  marché   de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, en détail, au comptant et  souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five member of the group Jantoyerela are married women averaging 38 years of age and three children. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in Sanoubougou II, a district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on their first collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. This group of women does commerce in foods, such as fruit and vegetables (in the case of Mariam C.), fish, tubers, and food catering. Mariam C. plans on using her loan to buy ten baskets of fruit (avocados). She gets her supplies at the big market and in neighboring villages from producers. The fruit is sold at the Sikasso market and as a family. Accepting cash and often credit, she makes her retail sales to a customer base composed of women and men. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 18,500 francs CFA. Part of the profit will be used for family expenses, and the other part will be invested in the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fruit

loans.name: Javzmaa

texts.en: Javzmaa S. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province, Mongolia in a ger (or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). Her oldest daughter, 17, attends a local secondary school. Her youngest two children, aged 10 and 7, attend a local primary school. During the day, Javzmaa helps operate a taxi service, and grows and sells vegetables. She used to run a retail business at the local Han-Ord market, but in 2008 opened the taxi service. Her husband took over primary responsibility for that business in 2009, while she went back to growing and selling vegetables. These two small businesses are how the family supports itself. Last year, Javzmaa planted vegetables on her father's land and the harvest was quite successful. She has been hoping to buy her own land on which to plant vegetables in the future. She is a very open and hardworking person, and has applied for a loan for 1,000,000 MNT loan to plant vegetables and to repair the car she and her husband use as a taxi.

loans.use: To plant vegetables and repair a taxi

loans.name: Snezhana

texts.en:
Snezhana is married and has one son. Two years ago she started a retail business selling shoes at an open market in Mukachevo city. She is a hard working person and has lots of energy to develop her business further by starting new locations.

Snezhana would like to purchase a boiler to heat water in her apartment. She does not want to take money out from her business. That is why she would like to get a loan. She needs 6,500 UAH to purchase the boiler that will allow her family to have hot water any time they need it!

loans.use: To purchase a boiler.

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Jiguiya est constitué de  cinq femmes, mariées dans des familles monogames, ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans,  2 enfants et habitant à Sanoubougou II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de pouvoir mener des activités génératrices de revenus. 
Ce groupe de femmes évolue dans le domaine de l’alimentaire en général tels  les fruits  et légumes avec Dialia Berthé, l’atieké et la restauration.
Dialia Berthé  qui est un des membres du groupe compte acheter avec son  prêt, 15 paniers  de fruits (mangues et avocats).
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso et dans les villages avoisinants. Les fruits sont vendus au  marché  Sanoubougou et  à l’intérieur du quartier à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Jiguiya is composed of five married women in monogamous families. The women average 36 years of age and two children, and they live in Sanoubougou II, a district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are on their first collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to be able to run income-generating businesses. This group of women works in the domain of foods, such as fruit and vegetables (in the case of Dialia Berthé, atieké (a kind of cassava couscous), and food catering. Dialia Berthé, who is a member of the group, plans on using her loan to buy fifteen baskets of fruit (mangoes and avocados). She stocks up at the grand market of Sikasso and in neighboring villages. The fruit is sold at the Sanoubougou market and within the district. Accepting cash and often credit, she sells retail to a customer base composed of women and men. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 19,000 francs CFA. Part of the profit will be used for family expenses, and the other part will be invested in the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fruit

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal B., 52, is a widow who lives with her daughter and two nephews in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). Her two nephews, ages 11 and 12, attend a local primary school. They have been living together in their current home for 10 years. 

Batjargal operates a bone setting and healing service in her town. She has been operating her business since 2005, and her business has become popular in her own province, as well as in surrounding provinces. Batjargal has greatly expanded her business over the past five years. Initially operating her business from her home, Batjargal has since moved to a formal workspace. Batjargal is an open person and focused on the future. She says, “There is almost no one else providing bone setting and healing services in my province. I have been planning to build another place from which to provide services for four customers with four beds. ” She is requesting a 1,400,000 MNT loan to purchase equipment for her bone settling and healing services.

loans.use: To purchase equipment.

loans.name: Nazgul Mukanbetova Group

texts.en:
Sometimes people need little guidance to see the real situation and make a right decision. Unfortunately in these cases, there is nobody to guide and give us sincere and correct advice or counseling. From this point, people who make these decisions themselves, relying purely on their intuitions and estimations deserve full admiration and respect. These people do not wait for the right wind, but adjust to the existing one and act accordingly. If taking risks and making tough decisions are needed, they do it, and thus prove for themselves. These types of people make a difference and deserve a different life. 

M. Nazgul is forty eight. She and her husband have been raising four daughters. The eldest daughter has turned twenty and the little one has turned nine. To provide for the family, Nazgul’s husband works as both a cattle breeder and a farmer. Nazgul works together with her husband and helps him farm their land. They have been farming the land for the last sixteen years and have become experienced farmers. During this time they have built a home and now want to give their daughters a college education. Nazgul has applied for this loan to pay for mechanic’s services and to purchase some amount of fuel. 

Nazgul’s partners: 

S. Orozbek, 55, is married and has four children. Orozbek farms the land and breeds cattle. His sons help him on the field and provide tremendous help in looking after cattle. Orozbek crucially needs fuel to finish farming the land. Therefore he hopes that he will be able to obtain this loan. 

I. Kundusbubu, 47, is a mother of two children. To make a living she and her husband are engaged in farming and raising cattle. Now, their children are studying at school, however, Kundusbubu is already thinking about her children’s future. She needs a loan to buy fuel. 

I. Mairamkul, 34, is engaged in a guest house business. She rents a guest house and leases rooms for tourists. However, her guest houses are traditional yurts - ancient houses of nomads, not ordinary guest houses. Her monthly income is around $330. Mairamkul needs a loan to make a tent over the yurts. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To pay for mechanic's services and to purchase fuel.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase fuel needed for farming

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina M., 32, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Alvin M. and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own food, accessory and ready-to-wear clothing stall for quite some time now.

Marina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her accessory and clothing business.

To ensure the success of her business, Marina would like to apply for a PHP 11,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more quantities of accessories and clothing to be incorporated into her current product inventory and also by buying raw ingredients for her food stall.

Marina dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a good, high quality education for her children.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more accessories and clothing to sell and fruit and raw ingredients for her food stall

loans.name: Gan-Ochir

texts.en:
Gan-Ochir B., 45, operates a truck-driving business. He lives with his wife and son in a ger (the traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent) in Hovd province, Mongolia. They have been living together for twenty-two years.

Gan-Ochir has been operating his business since 2000 and has built a loyal customer base. He has gained much experience in his business over the past ten years. To make money, he transports coal from the coal mine, and his wife sells it to individuals and organizations.

Gan-Ochir has been planning to purchase a larger truck in the future. With his business profits he provides for his family expenses. He is an industrious person and has been working hard to provide a better life for his family.

Gan-Ochir is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase coal and fuel to export coal to China.

loans.use: To purchase coal and fuel to sell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a 36-year-old married man who has three children aged between 14 and 1 year. He sells bananas wholesale in Nairobi after purchasing them from farmers. He has been running this business for five years and he terms his business environment as friendly.

Richard has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more bananas to sell. He dreams of being able to supply one full load of bananas weekly and employ at least five people.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell

loans.name: Davaajamts

texts.en:
Davaajamts P., 55, is married and the father of two children. He and his family live together in a ger (the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) in Hovd province, Mongolia. His youngest son, Luvsansharav, is a university student.

With his wife's help, Davaajamts operates a cafe at a local market. He has been operating his business since 2001 and has gained significant experience and built a loyal customers over the past nine years. With his business profit, he has been providing for his family expenses.

Davaajamts has also been paying his son's university fees with the profits from his business. In addition, he was able to purchase a truck for his oldest son, who lives separately from his parents.

Davaajamts has been planning to expand his cafe in order to provide his services to more customers. He is an open person and has many plans for the future. He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to expand and repair his cafe.

loans.use: To expand and renovate his cafe

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe sont  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivant  dans des  familles polygames à Bougoula Ville, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur onzième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait   le commerce  d’articles divers tels que la pomme de terre  avec  Sali B.,  le savon, de la friperie etc.
Sali compte acheter avec son  prêt, 30 caisses  de pommes de terre au grand  marché de Médine à Sikasso et effectuera sa vente au marché du centre de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500fcfa dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses familiales et les évènements sociaux et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group are married women in polygamous families with a median age of 34 and four children. They live in Bougoula Ville, one of the quarters of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their 11th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their clients' needs. All of their previous loans have been repaid in full. This group of women sells diverse articles like potatoes, soap, second-hand clothes, etc. Sali B. (a group member) counts on purchasing 20 cases of potatoes with her loan at the large market of Médine in Sikasso. She will make her sales at the market and at home to a male and female clientele. Sales are done in cash. Sali envisions making a monthly median profit of 17,500 FCFA. A part of the profit will be used to support her family's needs and for social events and the other part will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of potatoes

loans.name: Ayoko Nathalie

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente des produits de beauté et de ses accessoires dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet de se prendre en charge et de se subvenir à la plupart de ses besoins. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé mais aussi à Accra au Ghana le pays voisin. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 2006. pour éviter d’être en rupture de stock, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour lancer une commande de produits  de beauté.
texts.en:
This young woman’s business is selling beauty products and accessories at the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé. This activity allows her to pay for most of her everyday needs. She is buying her stock at the big market in Lomé and also in Accra in the neighboring Ghana. She launched this business in 2006. In order to avoid stock shortage, she is searching a loan from WAGES to place an order of beauty products.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing cosmetics and assorted items

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Né le 24 Mai 1982 à Sikasso, Monsieur Bakary Koné est marié, père d’une petite fille et vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie au quartier Mamassoni de la ville de  Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance de progresser à l’école, il s’est vite initié à cette activité génératrice de revenu, en optant pour la  coiffure des hommes et l’achat vente de matériels de coiffure depuis l’année 2000. Il jouit d’une forte sollicitation, réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes matériels de salon.
Afin de satisfaire cette clientèles de plus en plus nombreuses, il décida alors d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Bakary est à son premier prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter, 2 nouvelles tondeuses, 4 paires de peigne et brosses, 2 bidons d’eau de Javel, 3 bouteilles d’alcool de 90°, 5 bouteilles de pommade de cheveux, etc. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 85 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre  ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on May 24, 1982 in Sikasso, Mr. Bakary Koné is the married father of a young girl and lives in large traditional extended family in the Mamassoni district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having had the chance to progress in school, he was soon introduced to this income-generating business. In 2000, he opted to be a barber and to buy and sell hair care products. He enjoys a great demand and strong reputation, and he accommodates many orders for barber shop supplies. In order to satisfy his more and more numerous customers, Bakary decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his first loan, which will enable him to buy two new clippers, four pairs of combs and brushes, two containers of bleach, three bottles of 90% alcohol, five bottles of hair ointment, etc. With this loan, he envisions making a monthly profit of 85,000 francs CFA. With these profits, he plans on resolving his expenses and those of his family, paying the loan interest, and investing the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying supplies and equpment for his barber shop

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en: Kochkor village is located in Kochkor valley, surrounded by mountain chains in the south and the north. People of this area are used to harsh winds and frosty winters. The main occupation of majority is cattle breeding. Our group is not an exception. Damira B., the leader of this group, is the mother of three children. She is 48 and, for a living, she raises livestock for sale. At present, she is raising five sheep for sale. Her husband works in a rayon (district) electricity station. One of her sons works in a pastry shop while the other son and her husband help Damira look after the cattle. The little daughter has been fortunate enough, as her parents sent her to university in the capital. Damira strives to provide a good life for her family. Therefore she is doing her best to increase the total population of her livestock. Now, her monthly income is around $110. It is not much money but Damira is an optimistic person and believes that she will manage to improve her family’s living conditions. Besides, recently they have made a major repair to their house. Now, Damira needs a loan to purchase two sheep and fuel for farming. Damira’s partners: B. Aiymbubu, 60, is a widow who has raised three children. Her two sons are now farmers and actively support their mother. As for Aiymbubu, she is engaged in reselling livestock and manages to earn $85 a month. Now she needs a loan to purchase more sheep. S. Mairamkul, 49, has three children and the whole family is occupied with cattle breeding. They started this business three years ago by means of a loan and their life has greatly improved since then. Now they again need a loan to invest in increasing the total population of their livestock. T. Ishen, 56, is a widow and has three children: two daughters are married and a son is a college student. To make a living Ishen built a shop and started raising cattle. Now, she has a stable business and two sources of income. She needs this loan to purchase more sheep and a cow. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase two sheep and fuel needed for farming

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en:
Dolgor N., 39, is married and the mother of five children. She and her family live together in a ger (the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). Her husband operates a household and leather products manufacturing business. Four of her children are high school students, and her youngest son attends local kindergarten.

Dolgor operates a dairy products trading business at a local food market. She has been operating her business since 2000 and has steadily expanded her business over the past ten years.

During the summer, Dolgor purchases her products from the nearest soum (district) in her province. In spring and winter, she purchases her products from other provinces and from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The amount she purchases depends on her product sales. She cooperates on purchases with other traders in the same business in order to save on transportation costs.

Dolgor is an open person who has been working hard to provide a better life for her family. She is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy products from Ulaanbaatar.

loans.use: To purchase more diary products to sell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr:
Née le 28 Février 1984 à Sikasso ville, Madame  Catherine D.  est mariée, mère de 3 enfants et réside dans une  grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Banconi, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de 7 ans au petit commerce notamment  à l’achat-vente des pagnes wax, de tissus brodés, de chaussures en plastiques, etc. 
Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle surtout pour la qualité de ses produits.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est à son quatrième prêt individuel. 
Elle  sollicite ce 4ème prêt pour acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 4 complets de tissus brodés, des dizaines de paires de chaussures en plastiques en provenance de Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso)
Ces marchandises sont vendues de façon ambulante, dans les structures professionnelles et à domicile  à une clientele diverse et variée.
 Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born 28 February 1984 in Sikasso, Mrs. Catherine D. is married, the mother of three children and lives in a traditional extended family in Banconi, one of the boroughs on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After attempting several unsuccessful activities, she ventured into retail commerce some seven years ago selling pagnes wax (a variety of colourful West-African fabric), embroidery, plastic shoes, etc. She is in high demand because of the quality of her products. Wanting to satisfy an ever-increasing number of customers, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, where she is requesting a fourth individual loan. With this loan she will buy 10 lengths of pagne wax fabric, four sets of embroidered clothing, dozens of plastic shoes coming from Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). She sells her products as an itinerant vendor, in commercial structures or through home delivery, to a varied customer base. She hopes this loan will help her attain monthly earnings of 100,000 FCFA which she will use essentially to increase her working capital, contribute to family expenses and reimburse her loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Djénèba

texts.fr:
Âgée de 52 ans, Djénèba  Samaké est veuve et mère de 7 enfants qui  réside avec ses enfants dans la maison de son défunt époux à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de  quinze ans à cette activité d’achat et de vente des légumes ( gombo et aubergine, etc). 
Elle achète les légumes dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso qui seront véhiculés à Bamako pour être vendus. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ un an. Elle a bénéficié d’un prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association LAWASSA da Hamdallaye), elle est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Ce nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 20 sacs de gombo et 10 sacs d’aubergines  auprès des paysans producteurs avant de les revendre en détail et en gros aux commerçantes de Bamako.
 Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Djénèba Samaké is 52 years old. She is a widowed mother of seven children, living with them in her deceased husband’s home in Hamdallaye, one of the populous boroughs in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She did not have the opportunity to attend school, and began the retail commerce of vegetables (gombo, eggplant, etc.) over 15 years ago. She buys the vegetables in localities surrounding Sikasso, to be transported to Bamako for sale. Wanting to satisfy an ever-increasing customer base, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI about a year ago. She already took part in a solidarity (or group) loan with an association of neighbourhood women (LAWASSA of Hamdallaye association), and is now requesting her first personal loan. This loan will enable her to buy from the producing farmers 20 bags of gombo and 10 bags of eggplants, to be resold wholesale and retail to merchants in Bamako. She hopes to reach monthly earnings of 90,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to increase her working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay off her loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 35 years old. He is married to a business lady and they have six children. He is a member of Tushauriane Self Help Group where he gets his loans guaranteed.

Charles has been operating a retail shop in Nairobi for two years as well as a barber shop. He says that since he joined Faulu Kenya he has been able to save money.

Charles has requested a loan of Kes 50,000 to add stock to his retail shop such as sugar, flour, cooking fat and other products. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to grow his business into a wholesale operation.

loans.use: To add to his stock of sugar, flour and cooking fat

loans.name: Mahamadou

texts.fr:
Né le 23 Décembre 1985 à Sikasso ville, Monsieur Mahamadou  Diabaté est marié et père de 2 enfants, il réside avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle avec ses parents et ses frères à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Diabaté après l’activité de boulanger sans succès, s’est initié il y a environ 2 ans à la vente de matelas en provenance de Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso). 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Il sollicite ce premier prêt pour acheter, 6 matelas d’épaisseurs 1cm, 15 matelas d’épaisseur 20 cm “deux places”, 3 matelas d’épaisseur 20 “trois places”,etc. 
Il est très sollicité surtout par les menuisiers-ébénistes de la ville. Ses matelas sont vendus en détail au comptant et souvent à crédit.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born 23 December 1985 in Sikasso, Mr. Mahamadou Diabaté is married and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and children, along with his parents and his brothers, in a large traditional household, in Sanoubougou I, one of the boroughs on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Diabaté tried his hand at becoming a baker (unsuccessfully), then began some two years ago selling mattresses coming from Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). Wanting to satisfy an ever-increasing customer base, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, and is now requesting his first personal loan. This loan will be used to buy six 1-centimeter-thick mattresses, fifteen 20-cm-thick mattresses for 2 persons, three 20-cm-thick mattresses for 3 persons, etc. He is in high demand, particularly from town carpenters. He sells his mattresses retail, for cash and often for credit. He hopes to reach monthly earnings of 70,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to increase his working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay off his loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy mattresses

loans.name: Ainur's Group

texts.en: T. Ainur is the leader of this group. She is forty-five years old and has three children. Her two sons are sixteen and fifteen and her daughter is eleven. For Ainur’s family, living in a village does seem to be a burden, unlike many other villagers who leave villages because of an absence of opportunities for improving one’s living standards. Ainur’s husband has been working as a physics teacher in a local school. As for Ainur, she has been engaged in cattle breeding and increasing the total population of their livestock. Their stable income from raising the livestock for resale, is $90 a month. Ainur’s children have already learned the aspects of this activity and actively provide help when needed after school. Ainur and her husband are good examples of the category of people who prefer to make the best use of the conditions and opportunities available instead of blaming others for not being able to live properly. Recently they made a decision to make some changes to their house as well. They decided to build a new house and a separate bathroom. This is not an easy task and they need quite a lot of financial support. Therefore Ainur strongly hopes to obtain this loan to start building. Ainur’s partners: R. Lira, 51, has three children. Her husband works as a security guard and he also farms land. Lira is a housewife. Besides that, she keeps some cattle at home and thus helps her husband have an extra source of family income. Lira needs a loan to buy fuel, seed potatoes and wheat seeds for the family farm. I. Baktygul, 53, has four children and her husband is a private farmer. Baktygul is a language schoolteacher; she teaches both Russian and Kyrgyz. They also own a piece of land and now need a loan to buy fuel for farming. Z. Aftandil, 24, is single. He wants to get married and buy a car but he knows that to achieve this, he needs to work hard and earn a sufficient amount of money. He has already started saving money. Now he farms land and needs a loan to buy fuel and seed potatoes. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To start building a house

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Né vers 1968 à Sikasso, Monsieur Mamadou B. est marié et réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Mamadou B., après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au domaine de l’aviculture depuis l’année 2006. 
Il dispose d’une une ferme non loin de la ville de Sikasso où il y a des centaines de tête d’oiseaux (poulets, pintades, oies, dindons, pigeons, etc.) 
Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses volailles qui sont de bonnes qualités et bien suivis par des vétérinaires qualifiés. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel qui lui permettra d’acheter, des médicaments et nourritures pour la base cour.
 Avec ce prêt il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born around 1968 in Sikasso, Mr. Mamadou B. is married and lives with his wife and their children, in a large traditional extended household, in Sanoubougou I, one of the boroughs on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Mamadou B. unsuccessfully tried his hand at different activities, then began raising poultry since 2006. He owns a farm not far from Sikasso where he raises hundreds of fowl (chickens, guinea fowl, geese, turkeys, pigeons, etc. He is highly regarded by his customers for the quality of his poultry that are well controlled by qualified veterinarians. Wanting to satisfy an ever-increasing customer base, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, and is now requesting his first personal loan, which will enable him to buy medication and chicken feed. He hopes to reach monthly earnings of 150,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to increase his working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay off his loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy medication and chicken feed

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Âge de 38 ans, Monsieur Mamadou  C.  est marié et père de 2 enfants. Il réside avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle avec ses parents et ses frères à Wayerma I, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Mamadou C. est né et grandi  dans cette activité de vente de Quincaillerie car c’est le métier  qui fait vivre la famille depuis au temps de son père. 
Il connaît la quincaillerie en détail mais les moyens lui font défaut pour pouvoir satisfaire  sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter. Alors il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt qui  sera utilisé  pour acheter, 13 boîtes de peintures de 4kg, 15 cartons d’ampoules économiques, quelques unités de colles, de baquettes, de fil, d’eau de javel, de grésil, de disjoncteurs, etc . 
Il s’approvisionne au Ghana et en Côte d’Ivoire avant de les revendre en détail dans sa quincaillerie à une clientèle composée généralement d’architectes, d’entrepreneurs, de maçons, etc.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou C. is 38 years old, married and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and children, along with his parents and his brothers, in a large traditional household in Wayerma I, one of the boroughs on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Monsieur Mamadou C. was born and raised in a hardware store environment, as this has been the source of the family’s income since his father’s days. He knows the hardware retail business quite well but lacks the financial means to satisfy his increasing number of customers. He decided therefore to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI where he is requesting a first loan. The loan will serve to buy: 13 4-liter cans of paint, 15 cartons of energy-saving light bulbs, a few packs of glue, welding rods, wire, crésyl (disinfectant), circuit breakers, etc. He gets his supplies from Ghana and Côte d’Ivoire before reselling them retail in his hardware store, to customers who are for the most part architects, building contractors, masons, etc. The loan should help him attain monthly earnings of 250,000 FCFA, which will be used mainly to increase his working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay off his loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for his hardware store

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Theresa K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. She is 57 years old, is widowed, and has seven children who range from 13 to 36 years old. She was only able to attend school through 5th grade due to poverty.

For fourteen years, Theresa has been selling slippers on Mechlin Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.

Theresa plans to use her 10,400 Liberian dollar portion of this 47,600 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more slippers to sell. Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Theresa is the one holding the sign, and Rebecca F. is inset because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more slippers to sell

loans.name: Jack

texts.en:
Jack is 34 years old and married. He is the father of two children, aged 10 and 8. He has been a fishmonger in Nairobi for the last six years. He employs two people and describes his business environment as conducive. 

He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of fish for sale. Jack describes himself as honest and hardworking and hopes to diversify his business in the future. He also plans to educate his children well. 

Since joining Faulu Kenya Ltd., a Kiva partner, Jack says that he has adopted a saving culture and learned business skills.

loans.use: To add stock of fish for sale

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Miatta K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Sisters. She is 46 years old, married, and has five children who range from 9 to 23 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty.

For 18 years, she has been operating a mini restaurant in Via Town, Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner, which keeps customers returning.  She plans to use her 16,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 44,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, oil and pepper.
 
Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Miatta is the one holding the sign. Moore is in the inset photo because he was not present during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more rice, oil and pepper

loans.name: Ramatou

texts.fr:
Née le 02 Juin 1967 à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso), Ramatou O. est mariée et mère de six enfants, elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
Madame Ramatou O.  mène une activité d’achat et  de vente des condiments alimentaires il y a plus de trente ans, depuis très jeune auprès de sa maman. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre, elle décida  de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ sept ans. Elle a eu plusieurs  prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) avec une association des femmes à Kadiolo Noumousso et est maintenant à son 4ème prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce présent prêt, elle compte acheter, 12 cartons de  concentrée de tomate, 6 cartons de cube maggie, 3 sacs de graine de poivre, 3 sacs d’oignon séchés, 2 sacs de feuilles de Lorié, 5 cartons de moutarde et d’autres condiments au grand marché de Sikasso. 
Elle revend ses marchandises en gros, en détail, au comptant et à crédit,  aux consommateurs et aux détaillants du nouveau marché de Médine  où elle mène son activité. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Elle ambitionne devenir une grossiste au niveau du marché où elle opère afin de servir les détaillantes de ce marché qui ont souvent du mal à s'approvisionner facilement.
texts.en:
Born July 2, 1967 in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso), Ramatou O. is married and the mother of six children. She lives with her spouse and their children in Hamdallaye, one of the quarters of Sikasso. Mrs. Ramatou O. has bought and sold food condiments for 30 years, following her mom's work since she was very young. With the intention of better satisfying her ever-growing clientele, she decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso about seven years ago. She received several group loans with an association of women in Kadiolo Moumousso and is now on her fourth individual loan. All of her previous loans have been repaid in full. With this loan, she plans on buying 12 cartons of tomato concentrate, six cartons of seasoning, three bags of pepper grains, three bags of dried onions, two bags of Lorié leaves, five cartons of mustard, and other condiments at the large market in Sikasso. She sells her products at wholesale and retail. Sales are done cash and credit to customers and retail distributors at the new Médine market where she does her business. With this loan, she foresees making a monthly profit of 120,000 FCFA which she will use to contribute to her family's needs, pay the interest on the loan, and invest the rest in her business. She plans on someday becoming a wholesale distributor at the new market where she works in order to serve the retail distributors there who often have difficulty getting supplies.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Safiatou

texts.fr:
Âgée de 49 ans, Madame Safiatou D. réside dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses six enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Safiatou D., après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et  de vente de pâtes et tubercules de manioc afin d’en faire l’Attieke qu’ elle appris avec une voisine venue de la république de Côte d’Ivoire depuis plus de vingt ans. 
Elle mène son activité au domicile conjugal et est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a six ans. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association SABALY de Sanooubougou I), elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel, tous correctement remboursés. Madame   Safiatou D.  vend ses marchandises au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée très généralement de femmes. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 35 sacs de manioc à Sikasso et environnants  et 60 sacs de pâtes de manioc (Tièkèdoro) à Bouaké (République de la Côte d Ivoire) afin de les mélanger pour donner  un Attièkè de bonne qualité.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 230 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
At 49 years old, Mrs. Safiatou D. lives in a large family with her husband and her six children in Sanoubougou I, a popular neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (in the Republic of Mali's third administrative district). Mrs. Safiatou D., having headed many businesses unsuccessfully, has learned this occupation of the purchase and sale of cassava mash and tubers in order to make Attièkè [a couscous-like dish made from cassava], which she learned from a neighbor who came from the Republic of Côte d’Ivoire more than twenty years ago. She runs her business from her marital home and is highly sought after by her customers for the quality of her goods. In order to accommodate her increasingly growing customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso six years ago. After 3 group loans in partnership with the women of her neighborhood (Association SABALY from Sanoubougou I), she is on her 4th individual loan, all properly repaid. Mrs. Safiatou D. sells her wares for cash or credit to a customer base made up mostly of women. With this loan, she plans to buy 35 bags of cassava in and around Sikasso and 60 bags of cassava mash (Tièkèdoro) in Bouaké (the Republic of Côte d'Ivoire) in order to blend them and create a good quality Attièkè. She anticipates making a monthly profit of 230,000 CFA francs with this loan, which will mainly be used to grow her business, contribute to the family expenses and pay the interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cassava mash and tubers

loans.name: Lukia

texts.en: Lukia  is married with three children and all her children go to school. Lukia takes care of additional family members (her sister’s children). The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Lukia owns a stall selling second hand clothes and buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the biggest markets in Uganda. Lukia wants to use this loan of 400,000/ to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She has been in this clothing business for a very long time. Besides this clothing business, she also gets some money from rental rooms.  Lukia goes shopping once a week and uses public transport to and from shopping.  She doesn’t pay rent for her business because she works from her home. Lukia works six days a week and sells to all categories of people but only at retail. Business challenges include seasonality and the ever-increasing prices of second hand clothes. Lukia aspires to own a permanent business premise. Lukia joined MCDT because she wanted to access enough capital for her business.  Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en:
Carolyn is a 35-year-old lady. She is the single mother of one 8-year-old child who goes to school. She operates a tailoring and dressmaking business in Nairobi, a business that she has been running since 2002. She hopes to create more job opportunities for many other Kenyans by employing them in her expanded business in the future; currently, she employs three people. 

She has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of fabric for dressmaking. She also desires to build a residential house of her own and provide a good-quality education for her son. She is the treasurer of her group and describes herself as hardworking, visionary and committed.

loans.use: To add stock of fabric

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou D. est une femme de 36 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de MONTAGNE-SUD depuis le 09 avril 2009, en un an et demi elle a pu réaliser un bon niveau d'épargne. Elle est détentrice d'une cantine au marché central de Louga où elle vend des tissus. Son crédit lui permettra de renforcer son approvisionnement en tissus afin de faire plus de bénéfices et pouvoir participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou D. is 36 years old, married and the mother of five children, all under her care. She has been a member of the MONTAGNE-SUD “Banc Villageois” loan group since 9 April 2009, and in 1 ½ years was able to build up a good level of savings. She owns a booth in Louga’s central market where she retails clothing fabrics. Her loan will enable her to strengthen her fabric supply so she can increase her income and participate in improving the family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric for resale in her booth

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara is a 47-year-old lady. She is the mother of three children aged between 20 and 28 years, two of whom are in school. Sara is a tailor who makes clothes and sells them. She also sells cosmetics and food supplements. She employs one person in the business, which she has run since 2005. 

She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of fabric for dressmaking and also food supplements. Sara describes herself as committed and hardworking and hopes to grow her business, employ more people and construct a residential house within five years. She has learned record-keeping and customer-care skills from Faulu Kenya Ltd., a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To add stock of fabric and food supplements

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en: Immaculate is a single mother of six children and three of her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. Immaculate owns a bar in Nakulabye, one of the city suburbs, and sells all types of beer and local gin. She wants to use this loan of 600,000/= to buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin.  She doesn't incur any transport costs as she buys from her home. Immaculate has been in this business for 10 years. Besides this bar business, she doesn’t have any other side job. Immaculate works from her home and so doesn’t pay rent though she pays for an operating license. She sells to all categories of people at retail and at wholesale. Her major customers are mainly older men and women. Immaculate works seven days a week. Her business challenges include the rainy season and defaulters. She aspires to build a house to accommodate her bar.  She joined MCDT because she wanted timely loans.  Immaculate resides in and owns a four-room house.  The family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more beer and local gin

loans.name: Lingueres Keur Madiagne 2 Group

texts.fr:
le groupement les linguéres de keur maD. 2 est un sous groupe un groupement dénommé les linguéres de Fallokh
leur activité principale est la vente de legumes et céréales dans les marchés de la ville et des villages environnant comme le village de keur maD..Ayant bénéficié d'un premier prêt pour débuter leur activité ,ce second credit entre dans le renforcement de leur commerce pour acheter davantage de produits pour être revendu dans le marché et en tirer des profits pour faire face aux exigence de la vie et des depenses quotidiennes
texts.en:
The «Linguéres de Keur MaD. 2» is a subgroup of the «Linguères de Fallokh». Their main activity is the retail commerce of vegetables and cereals in town markets and in surrounding villages such as Keur MaD.. Having been granted a first loan to start up their business, this second loan will serve to strengthen their business by acquiring more products for resale, so that they can gain profits to deal with life’s requirements and daily expenditures.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: strengthen commercial activity

loans.name: Ndatté

texts.fr: Ndatté T. est âgée de 32 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants en charge. Elle a une ancienneté de 2 ans dans le Banc Villageois de MONTAGNE-SUD et y a reçu 4 crédits qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés sans aucune difficulté. Elle développe deux activités, la première consiste la vente de chaussures et la seconde la vente de noix d'acajou. Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son niveau d'approvisionnement, de mieux vendre et de faire des bénéfices qui feront qu'elle participe aux différentes charges familiales.
texts.en:
Ndatté T. is 32 years old, married and the mother of four children, all under her care. She has two years’ seniority in the MONTAGNE-SUD “Banc Villageois” loan group, and was granted four loans, always well managed and repaid without problems. She is developing two activities: the first consists of selling shoes and the second selling cashew nuts. Her new loan will enable her to increase her level of supplies and consequently her sales, and bring in profits that she will use to participate in various family expenses.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her revenue-generating activity

loans.name: Duke

texts.en:
Duke is a 21-year-old single man. He sells green bananas in Nairobi‘s Gikomba Market. He has been in this business for ten years, and describes his customers as dynamic. He has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add stock of green bananas. 

He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to expand his business to three times its size within five years.

loans.use: To add stock of bananas

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Amy

texts.fr: Amy S. est une femme de 61 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis le 29 mars 2008. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine, son crédit lui permettra d'acheter 5 moutons qu'elle va engraisser pendant au moins 5 mois et revendre au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. Cette activité lui procure des bénéfices qui lui permettent de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge familiale.
texts.en:
Amy S. is 61 years old, married and the mother of five children. She has been a member of the local “Banc Villageois” loan group since 29 March 2008. She fattens sheep, and her loan will enable her to buy five sheep she will fatten for at least five months to be resold at the weekly market fairs in her area. This activity will bring in profits that will allow her to help her husband manage the household.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy five sheep for fattening

loans.name: Ermelinda

texts.pt:
Ermelinda F. V. nasceu em inhambane onde frequentou os seus estudos em inhambane ate 5 classe  e nos tempos livres ajudava a fazer os trabalhos de casa e porque os seus pais nao tinham condicoes teve de vir a Maputo para viver com seu irmao mais velho  que se encontrava a trabalhar numa instancia turistica aqui na catembe.continuou com os estudos ate 8 classe e voltou a parar porque ficou gravida isto e 1996 e teve de trabalhar para o seu sustento e da crianca.com os rendimentos que ganhava do seu trabalho fazia pequenas poupancas onde acobaou conseguindo abrir uma barraca para poder exercer on seu proprio negocio isto e 2000 teve o seu proprio estabelecimento que vem exercendo a 10 anos e prendeu a fazer  o negocio no seu local onde trabalhava como empregada de balcao numa loja.
E atraveis de vizinhos ouviu falar da hluvuku onde  benefeciou  se de 1 credito no valor de 16.000.00 estando no Segundo emprestimo e ja teve outros emprestimos na cccom onde teve 5 crditos antes de conhecer a hluvuku no valor de 2.000.00,5000.00, 10.000.00, 15000.00, e 20.000.00.
 com o creditos o seu negocio vai crescer  e tambem os melhores produtos mais procurado na sua loja sao o arroz e acucar. E as vendas diarias tem sido de 1.500.00 dependendo dos dias quer dizer que aos fins de semana tem vendido mais principalmente quando ‘e final do mes e [para aumentar o seu rendimento tem de diversificar os produtos para conseguir ter mais rendimentos.
Agora vive na casa propria e o seu negocio vai muito bem tem conseguindo poupar algum parte do valor do seu rendimento fazendo depositos para sua conta particular.
Os seus projectos pessoais e poder um dia poder abrir uma crèche e formar um grupon de dancas para passarem a dancar em eventos tais como casamentos e outros.
texts.en:
Ermelinda F. V. was born in the town of Inhambane. Her schooling was interrupted in 5th grade, when, due to her family's financial difficulties, she was sent to live with her older bother in the province of Catembe, Maputo, where he was working at a tourist resort. In Maputo she started going to school again. After finishing middle school, in 1986, she got pregnant and had to start working as a store clerk to support herself and her child. Her earnings from that job allowed her to save some money to open a little grocery store. Since 2000 she has been in the business of selling foodstuff and beverages. Her bestselling products are sugar and rice. Ermelinda learned about Hluvuku from a friend, and this is her second loan with the institution (the first was in the amount of 16,000). In the past, she's had five loans from another institution in the amounts of 2.000.00, 5.000.00, 10.000.00 and 20.000.00mt respectively. This current loan will allow her to increase and diversify her stock. Since business is doing very well, she's able to save money in the bank. She makes 1.500.00/day (more on the weekends and at the end of the month) and owns the house she lives in. She hopes to be able to open a daycare one day, and to start a dance group to perform at weddings and other social events.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more rice, sugar, beer and beverages to sell at her store

loans.name: Roberto

texts.pt:
ROBERTO M. C. Como ‘e conhecido  por tio M., nasceu  em  Maputo a 51 anos no  bairro de guachene.vivia com seus pais numa familia humilde com muitos irmaos e sem condicoes frequentou o seu encino primario na escola da missao onde fez  a sua 4 classe e nos tempos livres ajudava o seu tio que era carpinteiro a trabalhar a Madeira, continuou com os estudos ate a 6 classe porque nao havia condicoes para continuar com os estudos teve de parar para trabalhar porque a vida estava dificil para familia e tinha irmaos novos que precisavam ir tambem  a escola.
Nunca mudou se   da catembe sempre viveu na catembe,  em 1975 comecou a trabalhar na carpintaria  com seu tio como ajudante assim aprendeu a fazer varias coisas dentre elas mobilias arros, portas e janelas.ganhou experiencia e houve a necessidade de ter uma carpintaria sua e foi fazendo pequenas poupancas ate  que com fundos proprios consegui u ter a sua propria  oficina.
Atraves de amigos  conhceu a hluvuku onde ja se benefecio de 5 creditos que foram para o uso no seu negocio de fabrico de varias mobilias .nunca teve outros emprestimos nos outros bancos.
Oe emprestimos que teve na hluvuku foram de 2.240.00, 10000,00, 10000,00, 11000,00,13000,00 e agora 20.000,00
A materia prima tem comprado na cidade isto ‘e a madeira,  que  compra  ao preco de 15000,00 cada torre e tem transformado em varias pranchas onde  fabrica cristaleiras mesas e mais. Mais o melhor produto que tem vendido mais  sao cristaleiras que variam ao preco de 8mil,10mil ate 15mil.
No final do mes  tem conseguido fazer  poupancas   e com este cr’edito pretende comprar uma torre e outros materias para fabricar mobilias e por num lugar estrategico para as pessoa s poderem conhecer o seu trabalho porque o que se verifica e que pouca gente conhece o trabalho dele e com este cr’edito o negocio vai crescer porque terei madeira para fazer varias mobilias e assim evito fazer so na base de encomendas.
E os desafios e sonhos pessoas  que ele tem sao expandir o seu negocio e diversificar a mobilia assim como fazer exposicoes nos sitios extrategicos ou onde ha maior concetracao de pessoas.
texts.en:
Roberto M. C., best known as Uncle M., was born in Maputo, Mozambique, 51 years ago. He had many simblings and lived with his parents in very poor conditions. He only studied until 6th grade and had to drop school to work. In 1975 he started working with his uncle, who was a carpenter, as his assistant. That way he learned to make several things from scratch, like furniture, doors and windows. He gained a lot of experience and felt the need to open his own carpentry workshop. He saved up and was able to open his own business. He heard of Hluvuku through friends, and has already had 5 loans with the institution, all used to improve his business. He thinks he needs to have a bigger amount of wood on stock in order to be able to build different furniture pieces and expand his clientele. He plans to expose his products in strategic spots where there's high circulation of people, so prospective buyers can see his work, since many people in town are still not familiar with the work he does.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wood for furniture business

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de pagnes et d'eau en sachet appelé "Pure WATER", elle fait ce commerce il y a 2 ans de façon ambulante et s'approvisionne au grand marché de lomé. elle veut éviter une éventuelle rupture de stock, c'est pour cette raison qu'elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat d'une vingtaine de pagnes et de 10 sachets d'eau pure WATER.
elle est célibataire et a une personne à sa charge.
texts.en:
This lady’s revenue-generating activity is the retail commerce of pagnes (colourful West-African fabric) and water packs of the “Pure Water” brand. She has been active in this business for the past two years, as an itinerant vendor, and gets her supplies fron the main market in Lomé. She wishes to avoid depleting her stock and therefore is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 pagnes and 10 “Pure Water” water packs. She is unmarried with one person to care for.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pagnes and "Pure Water" water packs

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is married with eight children and six of her children go to school. She takes care of her old mother.  Catherine resides and owns a one-room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Catherine owns a store selling charcoal.  She buys bags of charcoal from the villages of Luwero district and uses public transport to and from the villages. Catherine sells to all categories of people at retail and wholesale. She wants to use this loan of 600,000/= to buy more bags of charcoal. Catherine has been in this business for 10 years and also with MCDT for 10 years. She doesn’t have any side business apart from this charcoal business. She doesn’t pay rent for her business because she works from her home.  She aspires to increase her business and start selling at wholesale only. She joined MCDT because it was near her home.  Catherine’s monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Able God Group

texts.en:
Kulubo C. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Able God. She is 61 years old, married, and has two children, who are 26 and 28 years old. She also cares for a sibling. She did not have the opportunity to go college.

For five years, Kulubo has been selling used clothing at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, Liberia. She talks to her customers in a nice manner, which keeps them returning. But sometimes sales can be slow for her.

Kulubo started selling with 2,000.00 Liberian dollars as working capital. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used comforters for sale. Her goal is to expand her business to a large store in the near future. Kulubo describes herself as a serious and hardworking woman.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kulubo is holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more used comforters for resale

loans.name: Olimpio

texts.pt:
Olimpio A. J. nasceu em quelimane a 47 anos onde frequentou o seu Encino primario em Quelimane ate a 5 classe e nos tempos livres ajudava os seus pais nos deveres de casa e ajudava a cuidar tambem dos irmaos mais novos enquantos os pais trabalhavam.
 porque o pais na altura so lencionava ate 5 classe e teve de ir  a  Cuba para prosseguir com os estudos gracas a bolsa que ele ganhou onde frequentou da 6 ate 10 classe e de la foi chamado para cumprir com o servico militar obrigatorio ainda em cuba onde fez os treinos desde 1982 a1985 e volta  a Mocambique em 1985 e esteve afecto na Beira, anos depois foi transferido para Pemba,Mentagula e definitivamnete veio a Maputo onde encontra se a trabalhar a te hoje na MARINHA DE GUERRA DE MOCAMBIQUE  onde desempenha as funcoes  de ARTIlHEIRO que  aprendera  em Cuba a 28 anos,’e funcionario permanente no Estado onde vem desempenhando essas funcoes a 28 anos e o seu horario de trabalho das 7:30 as 15:30 e aufere um salario de 13.268.00 e consegue fazer poupancas no final de mes.casou se 1992 onde teve 2 filhos um de 16 anos e um de 14 e anos depois   a esposa veio a falecer e voltou a casar se no ano de 2003 e teve mais dois filhos um de 7 e um de 5 todos frequentam a escola.
Conheceu a hluvuku atraves de colegas seus e ja se benefeciou  de 5 emprestimo  este sendo o sexto emprestimo dentre eles 9.000.00, 16.000.00 20.000.00, 22.000.00, 10.000.00 e  agora 25.000.00.este emprestimo  ‘e para dar continuidade a sua obra  ja teve outros  emprestimos no BIM  no valor de 40.000.00 e 80.000.00.
Projectos pessoais para o future ‘e concluir a sua casa e um dia poder construir uma loja no seu bairro onde podera vender um pouco de tudo desde os produtos alimentares ate  materias de construcao porque todos tem de depender  da cidade de maputo para poder adiquir tudo o que as pessoas precisam e para tal vou precisar de novos emprestimos para poder concretizar o seu sonho.
texts.en:
Olimpio A. J. was born in Quelimane 47 years ago. He studied until 5th grade and in his free time helped his parents in house chores, and also helped raised his two younger brothers while his parents were at work. Back then, 5th grade was the highest level of education in Mozambique and Olimpio had to go to Cuba to continue his studies, thanks to a scholarship he received. He studied until 10th grade and from there was drafted into the army and did his training from 1982 to 1985. He came back to Mozambique in 1985 and still works as a Marine in the Marinha de Guerra de Mozambique. He's been working for the army for the past 28 years from 7:30AM to 3:30PM and makes around U$385 per month, which he uses to support his family and save. He's was married in 1992 and had two children, a 16 and a 14 year old. His first wife passed away and he later remarried, and had two more children, a 7 and a 5 year old. All his children are going to school. Olimpio heard of Hluvuku from friends and has already taken 5 loans, this one being his 6th. He wants to finish building his house and also build a small business nearby, where he'll sell a little bit of everything, from food products to building supplies. He thinks he has chances to succeed because right now everyone has to go to the neighbor city of Maputo to get basic things, and starting his business will be like a dream coming true.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cement, doors, windows, construction supplies

loans.name: One Love One Heart Group

texts.en:
Lue B. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called One Love One Heart. She is 43 years old, married, and has three children, who range in age from 21 to 24 years old. She also cares for eight siblings. She could not continue her education through high school because she started having children.

For 20 years, Lue has been selling dishes, such as plates, spoons and pots, in a shop at the Redlight Market in Paynesville, Liberia.
She talks to her customers in nice manner and sells her goods at a discount, which keeps customers returning. Sometimes sales can be slow for her.

Lue started selling with 3,000 Liberian dollars as working capital and now has about 75,000 Liberian dollars as working capital. She plans to use her 16,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 58,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more dishes, such as plates, spoons and pots, for resale. Her goal is to grow her business to a store, educate her children and improve the living conditions of her family.

Lue describes herself as a home mother and a devoted Christian.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Lue is holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more dishes, such as plates, spoons and pots, for resale

loans.name: Faida Group

texts.fr:
Cécile-Elide N.  est une commerçante âgée de 32 ans qui habite la Commune de Kinama en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle a une boutique dans laquelle on trouve divers produits comme les produits alimentaires, les produits de beauté et autres petits articles. C’est un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 5 ans. Elle a fait ses études secondaires avec un diplôme A2 en Gestion . Son époux, Kennedy N., est un chauffeur. Elle arrive au 2e cycle avec le crédit de Turame. 

Elle a 4 enfants : un garçon et 3 filles mais aussi prend en charge 3 autres enfants de sa famille proche.
