loans.use: To buy wood to build a fishing boat

loans.name: Ngoun

texts.en:
C. is 27 years old. She raises crops, which she harvests and sells when they come to maturity. She has been planting crops since 2005, and she earns a suitable income to meet her family's daily expenses. C. has a life partner in her husband, who works with her in the family business. The two of them have a young kid, who attends primary school.

Crop-growing is the main source of income for C. and her family. She needs to sustain and expand her business. In order to grow her business, she is now requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase more materials to grow better crops. The loan will allow her to increase the family's income.

C. and her husband are pictured above.

loans.use: To purchase farming materials

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia C. is from the town of Santa Josefa. She is 61 years old and has two children. To make a living, Ofelia plants rice and sells her harvest. She has been involved in farming for more than three years. She also started raising pigs to have an extra source of income. 

She joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ofelia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and to buy feed for the pigs. This will be her 8th loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business and pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and also feed for the pigs

loans.name: Doung

texts.en:
Doung N., 52, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She sells corn at a local market for an income of about $4 per day. Her husband is a farmer who grows fruit trees on his own plot of land, earning an average income of $4 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

N. is requesting a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike for her husband to provide transportation services as a motor-taxi driver. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S., 48, is married and resides with her husband and a twenty-eight year old child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She sells various kinds of groceries for an income of about $2 per day. Her husband is a mechanic, earning an average income of $2 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

She is requesting a loan of $500 to buy a plot of farmland to grow rice. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Ban Y., 57, is married and resides with her husband and a school-aged child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She is a tailor at home for an income of about $5 per day. Her husband is a soldier in the city, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  Y. is requesting a loan of $500 to repair her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to repair the house

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em V., 36, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She sells various kinds of groceries from her home in her village for an income of about $3 per day. Her husband works at the air force department in the province, earning an income of $4 per day to help cover the family expenses.  She is requesting a loan of $1000 to buy a motorbike for the family's use. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Yun

texts.en: The people who appear in the photo are Mrs. S. and her husband. This couple has an annual business, of which the main activity is to grow rice and vegetable crops. They live with two teenage children who are studying at secondary school. Besides the farming work, S. has another skill in breeding fish and she wants to use her knowledge to generate more income. She has recently dug a pond near her house where she wants to raise fish for extra income. Because S. doesn’t have capital, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy a stock of small fish to raise.

loans.use: To buy stock of small fish to raise.

loans.name: So

texts.en: So B., 30, is married and resides with her husband and a two-year-old child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She teaches Cambodian at a local primary school for an income of about $2 per day. Her husband is a teacher, too, earning an income of $2.5 per day to help cover the family expenses.  B. is requesting a loan of $500 to build a fence surrounding her house for the family’s safety. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. B.'s husband appears in the photograph at CREDIT's office.

loans.use: to build a fence for the family's safety

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en:
Nourn V., 47, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She grows vegetables and produces clay pots for sale for an income of about $4 per day. Her husband is employed at a non-government organization of demining (landmine clearance), earning an income of $4 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to buy vegetable seeds and a water pump to expand her agricultural products. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. V. is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: buy vegetable seeds and a water pump

loans.name: Moeuth

texts.en:
Mrs. Moeuth D., 36, is a crop cultivator. She has been doing this for the past seventeen years and earns approximately $3 per day. Her husband, Mr. Vireach, 40, is a military policeman in the village. They have four children, one of whom is employed and the remaining three are students and depend on the parent’s income. 

Moeuth D. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more farming supplies such as fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds to empower her to plant crops, and thereby increase her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase more farming supplies.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz L. is from the town of Santa Josefa. She is 49 years old, married and has seven school-aged children. She is involved in rice farming and hog-raising. Her husband does the major farming duties while she focuses her time on her hogs. She said that before joining CEVI, she had a sari-sari store and she used her income to buy piglets. Now, she just focuses on the farm and the pigs.

Paz joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Paz is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and also to purchase additional piglets and feeds. This will be her seventh loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for the farm, piglets and feed for them

loans.name: Rhyjil

texts.en:
Rhyjil C. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 26 years old, is married, and has two infant children.

Rhyjil got into farming way back in 2002. She plants rice crops and sells her harvest at the market. Out of her income from farming, she was able to buy piglets that she fattens and sells.

Rhyjil joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Rhyjil is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure and also more piglets to raise. This loan will be her fourth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure and more piglets to raise

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio A. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 48 years old, is married to Helen, and they have two children aged 11 and 14.

Rogelio owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over three years already.

In 2007, Rogelio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies. This loan will be his seventh from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies

loans.name: Duong

texts.en:
Mr. Duong V. has been a professional construction foreman for five years and lives with other family members in a small wooden house located in the rural area of Seim Reap, a province of Cambodia. He has another financial earner in his wife who sells a few types of dessert from home for a profit. This couple is blessed with six children who are no longer in school.

To help support the family’s daily expenses, two of their children own a boat that they use to provide a taxi service along the river. Currently, their boat breaks down often and their income has been affected. Duong V. will be using his loan to repair the broken boat and use the rest of the loan to grow his wife’s dessert business.

loans.use: To repair his sons' broken boat

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina D. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 47 years old and has two children.

Rosalina owns and operates a business raising crops. She also recently started raising pigs. She works hard to help provide for the increasing needs in her household. She hopes to have a stable income and better living conditions.

Rosalina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI.

Rosalina is now requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure and also feed for her pigs. This loan will be her seventh from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Hut

texts.en:
Mrs. Hut T., 37, is a professional fish catcher who has operated along the river for more than nine years. She and her husband always wake up in the morning and go to the river where they fish frequently. Also they hurry to bring their fish to sell at the market after they finish fishing. The couple has five school-aged children who are dependent on their income.

Hut T. needs a loan to buy a boat that they will use to travel to the middle of the river to fish. Hut T. intends to use any remaining money from the loan to accumulate more fishing equipment.

loans.use: To buy a boat for fishing

loans.name: Rosa Vilma

texts.es: Rosa Vilma C. D. R. D. 50 años D. edad, resiD. en Nueva San Salvador, ubicado en el departamento D. La Libertad. Vive junto a su esposo el cual se dedica a trabajar para una empresa privada. Rosa posee una tienda D. productos D. primera necesidad como comestibles y productos D. uso diario en el hogar, muchos productos poseen una gran demanda por parte D. las personas, las cuales Rosa desea mucho poder aumentar, ya que le permitirán tener mayores ganancias lo cual es muy importante para ella, ya que es gracias a la tienda que tanto ella como se esposo poseen una vida estable. Rosa solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en la tienda comprando productos como leche en polvo, pan, golosinas y sodas, entre otro número D. productos más. Rosa posee una gran ilusión D. poder ver su negocio en mejores condiciones y brindándoles el dinero necesario para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Rosa Vilma Cárcamo D. R., 50, lives in Nueva San Salvador, La Libertad department, with her husband whose employed by a prívate firm. Rosa has a grocery store where she stocks basic needs items like foodstuffs and daily home use items; many of the products are in high demand by people and Rosa wants to increase her stock amounts so that she can earn higher profits, which is very important to her, because it’s thanks to the store that she and her husband have stable lives. Rosa is asking for funds to invest in stock items for the store like: powdered milk, bread, sweets and soft-drinks among many other products. Rosa hopes to see her store’s condition improve so that it will produce income for her to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

location.town: Nueva San Salvador, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Shirley's Group

texts.en:
Shirley A. is from the village of Danipa. She is 35 years old. Shirley is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shirley A..

Shirley is single. To make a living, Shirley owns & operates a business selling a variety of different products in her general store. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 40000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Shirley has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Shirley from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Tien Hung1 Group

texts.en:
Bich T. N. was born in 1983. She lives in Tien Hung village, N. Khe commune with her husband and two of her children. Two of her children are still young. She grows and sells vegetables in the market. Her husband is a worker. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has a participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. She is the group leader of 5-member group loan in SEDA. In this loan cycle, she wants T. borrow 5,886,000 VND T. expand her business.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Minh T. T. was born in 1968. She has two children. She breeds the pigs and poultry. Her husband is a driver. They have a daily income. She wants T. borrow 5,886,000 VND T. use in her small business.
Hoa T. N. was born in 1982. She sells pork in the market. She has a son. Her husband is a worker. Mrs Hoa wants T. borrow 6,322,000 VND T. expand her business.
Hien T. Dao was born in 1971. She has two children. She has a store. She wants T. borrow 4,142,000 VND T. invest in her store.
Chinh T. T. N. was born in 1983. She has two children. She has a mechanic wokshop. She want T. borrow 5,886,000 VND T. expand her mechanic workshop.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Yuri Rosemery

texts.es: Yuri Rosemery A. M. de 33 años de vida, vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja para la policía Nacional Civil, junto a su pequeño hijo de 9 años de edad y su padre, residen en Ilopango, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Yuri se dedica a la venta de productos lácteos como crema, queso y requesón, así mismo comercializa carne de res y chorizos, su venta esta ubicada en el mercado de Ilopango, en donde posee varios clientes los cuales le compran semanal sus productos. Es por esta razón que ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más productos lácteos y así mismo más carne, ya que este es un negocio muy bueno y estable, el cual le brindar muy buenas ganancias, por lo que desea hacerlo crecer más. De esta manera Yuri desea poder superarse como comerciante y así mismo brindarle una vida mejor a su hijo en la cual posee todo lo necesario para tener una vida digna.
texts.en:
Yuri Rosemery A. M., 33, lives with her husband, who works for the National Civil Police, her 9-year-old son and her father in Ilopango, San Salvador department. Yuri sells dairy products like cream, cheese and requesón (similar to ricotta or cottage cheese); she has several regular customers that buy from her weekly. She needs funds to buy more dairy products and meat because this is a profitable and stable business and she wants to increase her sales and make it grow more. Yuri hopes to improve as a merchant this way and provide a better life for her son in which he has all that is needed to live a dignified life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dairy products and cream.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es: Pedro C. I. de 63 años de edad reside en el departamento de Usulután, lugar en el cual vive junto a su esposa, quien se dedica a viajar a Los Estado Unidos y traer ropa usada para vender. El señor Pedro se encarga de comercializar dicha ropa, la cual es traída del extranjero, y la cual comercializa en su casa de habitación, contando con la ventaja de que su hogar se encuentra ubicada en calle principal, esto es algo muy bueno sobre todo en los pueblos que son pocas las vía de acceso tanto para las personas como para los automóviles, lo que le da la ventaja de estar a la vista de casi todas las personas que ahí residen.  Pedro posee un negocio muy rentable, ya que ofrece ropa de muy buena calidad a muy buenos precios, así mismo que llama mucho más la atención ya que es traída del extranjero. Pedro solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para que su esposa pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa en diferentes estilos y tallas. De esta manera tanto el como se esposa esperan mejorar su negocio y así contar con todo lo necesario.
texts.en:
Pedro C. I., 63, lives in Usulután department with his wife who travels to the United States to buy used clothing to sell. Pedro sells the aforementioned clothing which comes from abroad; he sells it from home taking advantage of his home’s location along a main street. This is a very good thing especially in towns that have few access roads for people and cars; his being easily accessible to almost all the town’s residents is a real advantage. Pedro has quite a profitable business because he offers high quality clothing at very good prices; it’s highly sought-after because it comes from abroad. Pedro is asking for funds so that he can have enough money so that his wife can buy larger amounts of clothes in a variety of styles and sizes. In this manner, both he and his wife expect to improve their business and have all they need.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Heang N. is a local teacher who lives in a fallow village in Kampong Thom Province. Besides her teaching job, she also takes time to grow rice twice a year, during the rainy and dry seasons.

Heang N. has been farming since 1999, while her husband, Mr. Vorn, is an internal staff member in a non-government organization. Heang N. has given birth to three children who are now teenagers and are going to school.

This rainy season, which is the season for farming a rice crop, Heang N. is lacking some materials for her farming business. Thus, she requests a loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and rice seed for cultivating.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Sanilyn

texts.en: Sanilyn E. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 39 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Sanilyn owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. In 2007, Sanilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Sanilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and seed. This loan will be her eighth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's school fees. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly S. is an old mother blessed with a daughter who appears in the photo here. Ly S., 60, was married but her husband died of senility years ago.

To generate a daily income, Ly S. owns a small machine that she uses to provide a rice-milling service to neighbors. She also buys rice to mill and sell to raise more proceeds. She always receives help from her daughter to conduct her business. The rice commands a special price.

Ly S. is applying for a loan in order to buy rice to store and mill later to sell.

loans.use: To buy rice to store and mill later to sell

loans.name: Marianne

texts.en:
35 year-old Marianne M. and her family are one of the families who will be relocating from the land where they have lived for their whole lives. The owner of the said land is claiming his rights for personal reasons. Before his demand takes effect, Marianne hopes to have put up a savings fund through her transportation business. The business is managed by her husband and financed by the loan she availed from ASHI. Her membership to ASHI institution started in 2000. Since then she has received several loans, which enabled her to maintain the tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) for hire and to support their family's needs. Marianne’s parents gave the tricycle to her and her husband so that they could have their own source of income. As this tricycle has been used since 2004, its motor engine is no longer efficient. The sidecar is also very old and has to be repainted to be able to look nice and appealing to the passengers.

Marianne and her husband agreed to request for a larger loan so that they can purchase a brand new motorcycle. The repairs to the old one would cost a huge amount of money. Some of the money will be spent for repairs and repainting of the sidecar. Marianne is hopeful that once they have all these for their business, their income will grow and she will be able to have a savings fund. She hopes to save enough money to build their own house someday on the land owned by her husband's parents. Their old motorcycle will still be operating as a rental to have more profits to support her only child’s education until graduating from college.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and payment of the repair and repainting of the sidecar.

loans.name: Mei

texts.en:
Mei R., 54, is a humble, widowed mother blessed with three children. All three of them are now married and live together in the family home.

Mei R. has her own small business, the main operation of which is to buy merchandise in bulk from market suppliers and gain a profit by retailing them to regular clients who are fellow villagers living around the community. By doing this, she is able to generate $7 each day.

Mei R. has applied for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her son-in-law to use to pick up passengers for a fee. Through this, Mei R. is hopeful that she will have more income to pay the family’s expenses and her loan installments.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to start her son-in-law's transportation business

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a 49 year old lady who has been practicing farming since 2004 in Kiambu, Kenya.

Rachael plants trees for timber and rears dairy cows for milk production and supply. She describes her business environment as good and supplies her products to Nairobi.

Rachael is a member of Waiyaki Self Help Group whose members have guaranteed her a loan of Kes 50,000 from Faulu Kenya. With this loan, Rachael intends to buy another dairy cow to increase her milk production.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow

loans.name: Kahambu

texts.fr:
Kahambu M. est entrepreneur,productrice de boisson locale communément appelé « Rutuku »,excellente cliente de groupe solidaire, produit de graduation de l’IMF Hekima,  âgée de 66 ans, mariée, mère de 11 enfants dont 7 ont leurs propres foyers. Et les 4 autres étudient.Madame Kahambu M. réside dans le quartier populaire Birere - Kahembe, bidon ville de la ville de Goma. 
Son mari est aussi enseignant à l’école primaire Kajiga/Karisimbi.
Madame Kahambu M. a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre.Elle fut petite marchande, elle s’empruntait les intrants de production de boisson locale Rutuku(maïs, farine, bois de chauffage,etc.)auprès de ses amis et connaissances,qu’elle payait après l’opération sans aucun capital.C’était une façon de lui initier à l’auto prise en charge.De façon sommaire, Rutuku est une boisson  alcoolisée d’environ 47% produite en base de solution ou mélange des moisissures des Farine de manioc, maïs, sorgho, etc. chauffée au feu à plus de 180o C ,à travers une vase connecté à un cheminé d’évacuation de technologie locale.Les goutes raffinées d’évaporation issues de ce cheminé sont accueillies dans une cuvette et refroidies pour donner un gout d’une liqueur.Vue la charge de familiale,la prime ou salaire de son marie reçu auprès du gouvernement de la RDC est trop insuffisant pour couvrir les deux bouts du mois, ainsi  Madame Kahambu M. a développé d’autres activités supplémentaires entre autres la taillerie,le commerce ambulant de vente des habits et pagnes pour dames.Cela pour lui permettre de subvenir aux besoins de son foyer. Pour précision les petits bénéfices cumulés de son petit business de production boissons locale Rutuku lui avait permis de se constituer un capital pour acheter une machine à coudre et un petit fonds de commerce d’habit.En outre elle travaille aussi en collaboration avec son fils Jacques, ensemble, ils ont une kiosque publiphone et vente  des unités des mobiles cellulaires (réseaux vodacom, MTN supercell,Zain,CCT, etc.).Et peu plus tard, elle fut informé de l’IMF Hekima où elle a bénéficié de son premier crédit.
Avec le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Madame Kahambu M. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  2 sacs des Maïs, 4 sacs de farines maniocs, 12 pièces de pagnes,62 cartes d’unités pour publiphones,etc. 
Madame Kahambu M., explique le défi majeur de son activité de production de boissons locales Rutuku est lié aux ventes au crédit aux autres petits détaillants qui vendent dans les bouteilles et verres. En plus parfois lorsque le mélange des intrants n’a pas bien être solutionné,on produit une boisson non appréciée par les consommateurs, et les clients se réservent de l’acheter.
Dans l’avenir, Madame Kahambu M. reste très optimiste qu’elle souhaite diversifier  son activité  en vendant aussi la bière Primus et Les Fanta.Comme elle est encore locataire de la maison, elle souhaiterait  acheter sa propre parcelle et construire une maison et y exploiter une affaire commerciale stable. En plus, elle sera satisfait de voir tous ses fils se marient. 
Madame Kahambu M. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants
texts.en:
M. Kahambu is an entrepreneur who makes a local beverage known as “Rutuku” and is an excellent solidarity group client. A recipient of previous Hekima IMF loans, she is 66, married and the mother of 11 children, seven of whom have their own homes. The four others are students. Mrs. Kahambu lives in the busy neighborhood of Birere-Kahembe, a shantytown in Goma. Her husband is a teacher at the Kajiga/Karisimbi primary school. Mrs. Kahambu began her small business using her own funds. She did it on a very small scale, borrowing what was required to make the local drink Rutuku (corn, flour, charcoal, etc.) from her friends and acquaintances, whom she paid after production as she had no capital up front. It was a way of introducing her to taking care of her own needs. In brief, Rutuku is an alcoholic beverage, about 47% proof, brewed from a mixture of fermented cassava flour, corn, sorghum, etc. that is heated to more than 180C (356F) in a vessel connected to a discharge chimney (made using local technology). The droplets resulting from the evaporation process are collected in a bowl and cooled so the result tastes like a liqueur. Given the family expenses, her husband’s bonus or salary from the DRC government is insufficient to make ends meet each month, so Mrs. Kahambu has developed other businesses, including walking around selling women’s clothes and traditional African cloth (pagnes). This helps her meet the household expenses. More specifically, the small profit made from producing Rutuku has enabled her to save enough money to buy a sewing machine and establish a small clothing business. In addition, she works with her son Jacques. They have a public phone kiosk and sell cell phone cards (Vodacom, MTN Supercell, Zain, CCT, etc.). It was after someone told her about the Hekima IMF that she obtained her first loan. With this Hekima IMF loan, Mrs. Kahambu wants to increase her revenues by buying, among other things, two bags of corn, four bags of cassava flour, 12 pieces of African cloth, and 62 public phone cards. Mrs. Kahambu explains that the main challenge of her business of producing the local beverage Rutuku is selling on credit to other small retailers who themselves sell it by the bottle or the glass. Moreover, sometimes when the mixture of ingredients is not properly dissolved, the resulting beverage is not appreciated by consumers and customers are reluctant to buy it. Mrs. Kahambu is very optimistic about the future and wants to diversify her business by also selling Primus beer and Fanta. As she still rents her home, she would like to buy her own parcel of land and build a house on it so she can run a stable business. She also wants to see all her sons married. Mrs. Kahambu thanks the Hekima IMF for the loans she has received without any material guarantee because thanks to these loans, she is able to meet the needs of her children.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 2 bags of corn, 4 bags of cassava flour, 12 pieces of African cloth, 62 public phone cards, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dim

texts.en: C. is 31 years old, married, and lives in the province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia. Here, she and her husband have been establishing their own small family and working as local cultivators. The couple usually harvests and sells its crop when it is mature, and typically generates around $5 of income per day to contribute to feeding their one, school-aged child. C. depends on income from her farming business to support her child's studies. She will use her loan money to buy an additional piece of farmland for the purpose of cultivating rice crops.

loans.use: To buy an additional piece of farmland to cultivate rice

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en: Douglas is a 28-year-old man. He runs a kinyozi (barber shop) and salon in Nairobi. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to buy two dryer machines, two blow driers and a manicure machine. Douglas serves the low-income earners from the Mukuru slums and describes his business as busy. A humble, honest and goal-oriented man, Douglas hopes to own a chain of beauty shops, buy a piece of land, build both commercial and residential houses, and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy two dryer machines, two blow driers and a manicure machine

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley B. is 43 years old and from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Shirley owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years.
In November 2008, Shirley joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her fourth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married. She runs a small business selling cups, vases and other ceramic items. Her business is located at the central market in Zaporozhye. This good location brings in many customers and makes her business a success. Nataliya has been in this business for 12 years.
The business brings a stable income to Nataliya's family. She can even help her children's families. Her goal is to develop the business further, rent a larger facility and begin selling items in bulk. She would like to borrow 7,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and earn additional income.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan F. is 49 years old and from the town of Sta. Josefa. She has six school-aged children. To make a living, Susan owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Susan has been engaged in her business for over ten years.
In 2007, Susan joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Susan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her eighth loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Lumiere Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Lumière sont des  6 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 6 enfants et vivant  dans des  familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.Tous  les prêts précédents ont  été correctement remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles  divers tels que la préparation et vente de l’encens par Mariam Dembélé, l’achat vente du bois de chauffe, des gingembre etc.
Mariam compte acheter avec son  prêt  20kg de guenni + 10kg de magnon kisenin. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des grossistes.
Les encens prêts à l’utilisation sont vendus au  marché d’HAMDALLAYE et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the Lumière group are all married women. Their average age is 33 and they have, on average, 6 children. They live in polygamous families in Hamdallaye, a neighbourhood in Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali).
In order to meet the needs of their customers, they are on their fifth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They have repaid all of their previous loans.
These women work in various trades, buying and selling firewood, ginger etc. Mariam Dembélé makes and sells incense. Mariam plans to buy 20kg of guenni and 10kg of magnon kisenin with her loan. She buys her stock from wholesalers at the big market in Sikasso.
She sells the ready-to-use incense at the Hamdallaye market and within her family, mostly to women. Her customers pay with cash and often with credit.
She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 18.500 FCFA, part of which will go towards family expenses and the rest will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to make incense

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita C. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 62 years old. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years already.

In 2007, Teresita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Teresita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans,  5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts antérieurs se sont bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que l’encens avec  Aoua Konté, le bois de chauffe, le gingembre,  les vêtements etc.
Aoua Konaté compte acheter avec son  prêt,  20kg de guenni + 10kg de magnon kisenin. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et effectue sa vente au  marché d’ HAMDALLAYE et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
NB : On note l’absence de Kadia Koné sur la photo, due à la maladie brusque de son enfant.
texts.en:
The seven members of this Sabougnouma group are essentially married women with an average age of 32 and on average 5 children, most of whom live in polygamous families in HAMDALLAYE, a neighborhood of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with a view to satisfying their clientele. All their prior loans have been correctly resolved. This group of women sell various articles such as incense in the case of Aoua Konté, firewood, ginger, clothing, etc. Aoua Konaté intends to use her loan to buy 20 kg of "guenni" and 10 kg of "magnon kisenin" (ingredients for making incense). She buys her supplies in the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso and sells her products in the market of HAMDALLAYE and among her family members, to a clientele composed of women, for cash and often for credit. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 11,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the rest reinvested in the business. Her ambition is to increase her sales and better satisfy her clientele. Note: Kadia Koné is not in the photo due to the sudden illness of her child.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy perfumes and other ingredients for making incense

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a widow. She's got two adult sons who left the family. Tatyana sells women's clothing at an open market in Berdyansk town. She has been in this business for 12 years and knows it well. 

Tatyana would like to improve her business conditions. She hopes to cover the sides of her kiosk with metal or other material to prevent rain, dust and sunlight from getting in and spoiling the inventory. Tatyana would like to borrow 7,000 UAH so she does not need to take money out of her business.

loans.use: To improve business conditions

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a hardworking businesswoman, 33 years old, who sells bananas and she has been in this business for a long time. As she is not married, she always works hard so that, in the future, she will be able to help her future family with everything.

With the goal of being financially stable, Christine would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which hopefully will allow her to expand her business. She will use the loan to purchase a large quantity of bananas to keep reinvesting in her future.

With the use of this loan, Christine hopes that her sales will increase as well as her profits. By accessing this loan, she has a hope for the future.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of bananas to sell

loans.name: Ephraem

texts.en: Ephraem, a 41-year-old businessman, is the married father of four between the ages of 12 years and 1 month, three of whom are in school. He owns a retail shop in Nairobi where he sells food products, household products and utensils, a secure business he has been operating for three years. Ephraem is requesting a loan of Kes. 40,000 to add stocks of sugar, rice, flour and utensils, a loan guaranteed by his group members. Describing himself as progressive, he hopes to grow his business into wholesale in five years.

loans.use: To add stocks of sugar, rice, flour and utensils

loans.name: Honronkantigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Honronkantigui est de  huit  femmes mariées, ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans,  4 enfants et  habitant à Kafela  un des villages de la préfecture de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur treizième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers les céréales, le bois de chauffe et de charbon de bois à l’image de Djenebou S..
Djenebou compte acheter avec son  prêt, 2 tonnes de charbon de bois.Elle s’approvisionne dans le dit village et dans les villages  voisins.
Elle les revend aux passants au bord du goudron et  à Sikasso ville les jours de foires hebdomadaires, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille (scolarité des enfants et mariages) et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Honronkantigui group is made up of eight married women who average 40 years old with four children. They live in Kafela, one of the villages of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their thirteenth collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better meet their clients' needs. This group of women sells diverse articles like grains, firewood, and wood charcoal. Djenebou S., one of the members, counts on purchasing two tons of wood charcoal with her loan. She stocks up on supplies in her village and in neighboring villages. She sells charcoal to passer-bys on the asphalt road and in Sikasso village at the weekly fair. She makes her sales in cash to a clientele composed of men and women. She foresees making a median monthly profit of 15,500 FCFA which she will use to meet her family's needs (education and marriages of her children) and invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wood coal

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah is a hardworking and focused 41-year old mother of three children between the ages of 15 and 9 years, all of whom attend school. She is married to a government employee and desires to educate her children to university level.

Zipporah owns a posho mill and sells flour, maize, beans, muthokoi (ground maize) and other food products. She also sells charcoal, operates a tailoring shop and rears chickens. Zipporah employs one person and sells her products to her neighbours. A member of Key Venture Self Help Group, whose members have guaranteed her loan request of Kes. 40,000 from Faulu Kenya, she will use the funds to add more chicks.

loans.use: To add more chicks

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Jiguisseme est constitué 4  femmes mariées, ayant une moyenne d’âge de 44 ans, 4 enfants et habitant à Kafela  un des villages de la préfecture de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur treizième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles  divers tels  le  charbon de bois avec Mariam  Dembélé,  la bouillie,  les fruits et légumes etc.
Mariam Dembélé compte acheter avec son  prêt, 25  sacs de charbon de bois.
Elle s’approvisionne dans le dit village et dans les villages  voisins.
Elle revend aux passants au bord du goudron et  à Sikasso ville les jours de foires hebdomadaires, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille (scolarité des enfants et mariages) et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
This Jiguisseme group is made up of four married women with an average age of 44 and 4 children on average, who all live in Kafela, a village in the prefecture of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They are on their 13th collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with a view to satisfying the needs of their clientele. This group of women sell various items such as charcoal, in the case of Mariam Dembélé, and also porridge, fruit and vegetables, etc. Mariam Dembélé intends to use her loan to buy 25 sacks of charcoal. She buys the charcoal in her village and in surrounding villages and sells it to passersby along the paved road and in the town of Sikasso on weekly marketdays, to a clientele composed of women and men for cash. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 15,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family expenses (school fees and wedding expenses) and the rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying charcoal for resale

loans.name: Akilimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les six  membres du groupe Akilimaya sont de femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans,  4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à KABOILA II  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce général avec Mariam D. dans l’achat vente de concombres, le bois de chauffe, des  vêtements pour enfants, le savon liquide, etc.
Mariam D. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  15 sacs de 100kg de concombres
au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les jardins des villages avoisinants auprès des producteurs.
Elle revend au  marché de Mancourani I et en famille à une clientèle composée  de femmes, en détail, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the Akilimaya group are married women with an average age of 28 and 4 children on average, living for the most part in polygamous families in KABOILA II, one of the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for the third time with a view toward satisfying the needs of their clientele. Both the preceding loans were correctly resolved. This group of women engages in general commerce. Mariam D. sells cucumbers, but others sell firewood, children's clothing, liquid soap, etc. Mariam D. intends to use her loan to buy 15 sacks of 100 kg of cucumbers in the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso and directly from producers in the surrounding villages. She sells the cucumbers in the market of Mancourani I and among her family members, to a clientele composed of women, retail, for cash and often on credit. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 17,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the rest reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying cucumbers for resale

loans.name: Tujikwamue Kiburunga Group

texts.en:
Lucy T., the President of the Tujikwamue Kiburugwa Group, is 32 years old, married, and has two young daughters, ages three and nine. Lucy runs a small café selling milk, juice, soda, and water. She also sells Irish potatoes at a small stand beside the café. Lucy has been running her café for a year, working from about 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. each day.

With Lucy's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, she was able to purchase cooking oil and milk. Having repaid that loan, she will use this one, her second, to restock her milk inventory and add more Irish potatoes. Lucy's dream is that with increased profits from her business, she will one day be able to renovate and expand her family's small home.

Lucy will share this loan with her group, whose 23 members run a variety of businesses including sales of food, charcoal, fish and poultry. They hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, Lucy is in the middle row, towards the right. She is wearing a yellow and green shirt.

loans.use: Buying milk and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick, a 37-year-old businessman, has been selling industrial chemicals and soap in Nairobi for the last ten years and terms it profitable. He is now requesting a loan of Kes. 40,000 to add a stock of industrial chemicals and purchase containers for packing soap. Describing himself as hardworking and determined, Patrick hopes to buy a house and have a well-established industrial chemicals shop in five years.

loans.use: To add a stock of industrial chemicals and purchase containers for packing soap

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont essentiellement des  femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans,  3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à OUAYERMA I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali.) 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, tous les prêts passés  se sont  bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes  excelle dans le commerce d’articles divers, tels les condiments alimentaires avec Awa Dembélé, le  bois de chauffe, le lait,  les pagnes wax etc.
Awa compte acheter avec son  prêt,  5 paquets de condiments alimentaires (cube maggi, huile de palme, sel de cuisine, oignons , choux, concentrée de tomate, poivre, poudre de gombo, les poissons séchés etc)
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans des villages avoisinants. Elle les revend au  marché de OUAYERMA I et en famille à une clientèle composée  de femmes au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi are essentially married women averaging 37 years of age and three children living for the most part in monogamous families in OUAYERMA I, a district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women are on their sixth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers.  All their previous loans were settled.  This group of women excels in the commerce of various goods, such as condiments (as with Awa Dembélé), firewood, milk, wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), etc.  Awa plans on using her loan to buy five packets of condiments (Maggi bouillon cubes, palm oil, table salt, onions, cabbage, tomato paste, black pepper, okra powder, dried fish, etc.).  She gets her supplies at the big market of Sikasso City and from neighboring villages.  Accepting cash and often credit, she resells as a family to customers composed of women and men at the OUAYERMA I market. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 20,500 francs CFA.  Part of the profit will be used for family expenses, and the other part will be invested in the businesses.  Her ambition is to increase her sales to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying condiments

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is the mother of five children aged between 18 and 5 years. All her children are in school.

Florence runs a grocery shop in Nairobi where she deals in cabbage, sukumawiki (kale), fruit and other products. She has been running this business for eight years and terms her business good.

Florence has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 to add to her stock of cabbage, kale and fruit. She describes herself as visionary and hardworking and hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of cabbage, kale and fruit

loans.name: Ami

texts.fr:
Mademoiselle  Ami Boré est âgée de 27 ans et mère d’une petite fille. Elle réside chez ses grands parents maternels à Sanoubougou II, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la République du Mali). 
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer aux études, Ami  s’est vite initiée à la coiffure féminine depuis environ onze ans. 
Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, elle est très sollicitée par les jeunes demoiselles surtout lors des cérémonies (mariages, baptêmes, anniversaires, etc.). L’insuffisance des ressources propres  pour bien mener cette activité constitue l’objet et la justification de sa demande de prêt à Soro Yiriwaso afin de mieux satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter. 
Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de deux  ans et est à son deuxième prêt individuel après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.
 Elle sollicite ce deuxième prêt pour acheter, 2 robes de mariés, 10 paquets de mèches de différentes qualités à Bamako. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce deuxième prêt, un bénéfice moyen 100 000 FCFA lui permettant de résoudre ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Ami Boré, aged 27, is the mother of a young girl.  She resides with her maternal grandparents in Sanoubougou II, a working-class district in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to advance at school, Ami was introduced to women's hairdressing about eleven years ago.  With such experience in this domain, she is in high demand by young ladies, especially for ceremonies (marriages, baptisms, birthdays, etc.)  The lack of her own funds for running this business has to do with the goal and justification for her loan request at the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  The loan is for doing better in satisfying the needs of her customers, who are ever-increasing.  Ami has had an association with Soro Yiriwaso for over two years and is on her second individual loan after having properly repaid her first one.  She is requesting this second loan to buy two wedding dresses and ten packets of hair extensions of different qualities, in Bamako (capital of Mali).  Ami envisions using this loan to make an average profit of 100,000 francs CFA, which will enable her to resolve her personal expenses, to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Madougou

texts.fr:
Madougou Sangaré est une veuve de 63 ans, qui réside avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants chez leur défunt époux à Mancourani II, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, Madougou s’est vite initiée aux activité de petit commerce de pagnes wax et de tissus brodés  depuis plus de trente ans. 
Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des femmes) pour la qualité de ses produits. Elle reçoit beaucoup de commandes des localités environnantes et son activité marche en merveille.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ sept ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, il est à son dixième prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                      Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 24 pièces de pagnes wax, 18 complets de tissus brodés et 10 paires de chaussures en  plastique. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako ensuite elle les revend de façon ambulante à Sikasso et souvent dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 180 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Madougou Sangaré is a 63-year-old widow who resides with her co-wife and their children in the home of their deceased husband, in Mancourani II, the downtown area of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to advance at school due to societal reasons, Madougou was soon introduced to businesses involving commerce in wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth) and embroidered cloth, over thirty years ago.  She is much in demand, especially by her customer base (composed essentially of women), for the quality of her products.  She receives many orders from the surrounding towns and her business is doing very nicely.  Concerned about further satisfying her burgeoning customer base, Madougou decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about seven years ago.  After several solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her district, she is now on her tenth individual loan.  All the previous ones were properly repaid.  She plans on using her loan to buy 24 bolts of wax pagnes cloth, 18 outfits of embroidered fabrics, and 10 pairs of plastic footwear.  She gets her supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali) and then resells them door-to-door in Sikasso and often in the towns surrounding Sikasso.  Madougou envisions using this loan to make a monthly profit of 180,000 francs CFA, which will be used essentially to increase her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is a 24-year-old business lady. She is married to a doctor and they have two children who are in school.

Millicent sells charcoal in Machakos and describes her business as busy. She also rears livestock to earn extra income.

Millicent has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 to add to her stock of charcoal to sell. She hopes to be the main charcoal supplier in her town and describes herself as hardworking.

In the future, Millicent desires to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To add to her stock of charcoal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sali

texts.fr:
Âgée de 46 ans, Sali B. est une femme mariée et mère de six  enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Mamassoni, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).                       
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’est vite initiée depuis plus de dix ans à cette activité de petit commerce d’achat-vente de pagnes wax , de tissus brodés,  de bazins teintés, etc. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des femmes) pour la qualité de ses produits.  
 Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de cinq  ans. Elle a bénéficié  de plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier et  est actuellement à son onzième individuel qui lui permettra d’acheter 15 pièces de pagnes Wax, 6 complets de tissus brodés, 5 complets de bazin “moins riche” en couleur à Bamako.                                                                                                         Elle dispose d’une place au niveau de marché de leur quartier où elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes. Elle amène souvent ses marchandises dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso les jours de leur foires pour être vendues.                                                                                                            Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 190 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
46 years of age, Sali Mamba is married and the mother of six children. She lives with her husband and children in Mamassoni, an outer district of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Not having had an opportunity to attend school for social reasons, about ten years ago she quickly launched a small business buying and reselling wax “pagnes” [traditional fabric for wrap clothing], embroidered fabrics, dyed “bazins” [a type of damask cloth highly prized in West Africa], etc. Her business is very popular with her customers (mostly women) due to high quality of her goods. In order to better meet the demands of her growing customer base, five years ago she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. She had benefitted from several “solidarity” loans (group loans) in the past, and is now on her 11th individual loan, which will allow her to purchases 15 sets of wax “pagnes,” six sets of embroidered cloth, and five sets of dyed “bazins” of mid-range quality in Bamako. She has a vendor spot at the local market, where she sells her goods in cash or on credit to a customer base composed essentially of women. She often brings her goods to other areas around Sikasso in order to sell them on local market days. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly income of 190,000 West African francs, which will be mainly used to bolster her business capital, contribute to the family budget and pay off the interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for traditional apparel

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Sylvain

texts.fr:
Né le 30 Décembre 1971 à Mandiakuy préfecture de San (région de Ségou), Monsieur Sylvain D. est un technicien Orthopédiste à l'hopital régional de Sikasso. Marié et père de trois enfants, il réside  avec son épouse et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  D. en marge de ses activités professionnelles, il dispose une ferme située à environ  7km de la ville de Sikasso où il mène l’élevage de porcs et l’aviculture depuis plus de deux ans. 
Dans le but de mieux mener cette activité qui lui est très rentable, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y’a 3 ans environ. Il a bénéficié d’un premier prêt qui a été correctement remboursé, il sollicite ce deuxième prêt pour acheter, 5 paires de porcs, 2 paires de oies et 3 paires de dindons.
 Avec ce prêt il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on December 30, 1971 in Mandiakuy, San Prefecture (Ségou Region), Mr. Monsieur Sylvain D. is an orthopedic technician at the regional hospital of Sikasso.  Married and the father of three children, he resides with his wife and their children in Sanoubougou I, a working-class district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Aside from his professional work, Mr. Dakou has a farm located about 7 km from Sikasso City, where he has been running a farm for raising pigs and poultry for over two years.  But with the goal of improving this business, which is very profitable for him, Mr. Dakou decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about three years ago.  He has benefited from an initial loan, which he repaid properly.  He is requesting this second loan for buying five pairs of pigs, two pairs of geese, and three pairs of turkeys.  With this loan, he envision making a monthly profit of 120,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for increasing his working capital, for helping to cover family expenses, and for paying the loan interest. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pigs

loans.name: Venuste

texts.en:
Venuste is 27 years old, single, and struggles by selling a variety of goods in his shop. He has been in this business for about two years and the hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Venuste, after realizing that his sales are not enough to earn more profits, would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that he can purchase more rice, sugar, salt, Irish potatoes, beans, etc.

With these additional goods for sale, Venuste hopes that his profits will increase and these profits will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for his store

loans.name: Prum

texts.en:
Prum C. Y. is a 51-year-old married woman and mother. To earn a living, she bought a machine that she uses to squeeze sugarcane to obtain juice to sell. She typically earns an average of $3 per day to help control all her family’s financial problems.

Prum C. Y. has another financial earner in her husband who drives a truck for a small firm, getting a suitable monthly salary. This couple helps each other in order to generate money to help support their three school-aged kids, while another one is now married and employed as a taxi driver.

Prum C. Y. wants to make additional earnings and is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a cart that she will use to sell fried meatballs as a mobile vendor around her community.

loans.use: To purchase a cart to start selling fried meatballs

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame Aminata C. est une femme de 35 ans et mère de 4 enfants qui vit avec ses enfant chez son époux dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Ayant abandonnée l’école dès à son jeune âge, elle s’intéressa très vite aux activités génératrices de revenus, à l’achat vente de savons et présentement à la préparation vente de glaces et de jus de boissons non alcoolisées.
Après un premier prêt correctement remboursé, elle est au deuxième qui sera utilisé pour acheter, un congélateur. 
Elle s'approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) et vend essentiellement chez elle même à domicile à une clientèle diverse et variée.
Elle compte réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aminata C. is 35 years old and the mother of four children. She lives with her children and her husband in the North Hérémakono borough of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having quit school at an early age, she became quickly interested in revenue-generating activities, such as buying and selling soap, and currently the preparation and sale of ice pops and non-alcoholic beverages. Having fully reimbursed her first loan, she is now requesting a second loan to buy a freezer. She resupplies in Bamoko (capital of the Republic of Mali) and sells mainly from her home, but also through home delivery, to a varied and diverse customer base. She hopes this loan will help her attain monthly earnings of 65,000 FCFA she will use to expand her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a freezer

loans.name: Jimna

texts.en:
Jimna is a 31-year-old businessman. He owns Furaha Hardware where he sells bicycle spare parts in Nairobi, Kenya. His customers are mainly cyclists and people who repair bicycles.

Jimna has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 to add to his stock of bicycle spare parts and this loan is guaranteed by United Self Help Group.

Jimna is married to a teacher and they have a 6-year-old son who goes to school. Jimna hopes to improve his life and describes himself as ambitious.

loans.use: To add to his stock of spare parts

loans.name: Abibata

texts.fr:
Madame Abibata Kouyaté est âgée de 63 ans, mariée et mère 9 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari avec leurs enfants dans une famille nucléaire  au  quartier Missira de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle commença très tôt le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. 
Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à côté de cette dernière jusqu’à son mariage, elle mena beaucoup activités génératrices de revenus mais finit par opter la préparation et vente de l’encens. 
Elle  mène cette  activité  depuis 15 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
 Dans le dessein de faire face à la demande clientèle,  elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 72 mois, après avoir fait 6 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 4ème prêt. 
Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter, 20kg de sarakatanés et 10kg de magnonkiséni. Elle s’approvisionne en  République Islamique de Mauritanie et effectue sa vente, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 60 000 FCFA, qui lui permettra de subvenir à certaines de ses charges (habillements, savons et médicaments). 
Son ambition est  de se  construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Abibata Kouyaté is 63 years old, married and the mother of nine children. She lives with her children and her husband in a single-family household in the Missira borough of Segou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She began taking part in commercial activities at an early age, helping her mother sell food condiments. She spent several years with her as an apprentice until she married, after which she tried her hand at many activities to finally opt for the preparation and sale of incense. She has been running her business for 15 years and enjoys a solid reputation and a large customer following. In order to meet customer demand, she approached Soro Yiriwaso 72 months ago. After six group loans and three personal loans, all repaid in full, she is now requesting a fourth personal loan. The loan will be used to buy 20 kilos of sarakatané (bark from an Arabian tree) and 10 kilos of magnonkiséni (a plant). She gets her supplies from the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, and sells her product for cash or credit to mainly women customers. She hopes to attain monthly earnings of 60,000 FCFA, which will enable her to meet some of her needs (clothing, soap and medication). Her ambition is to build herself a dwelling.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to prepare incense

loans.name: Tata

texts.fr:
Madame Tata S. est âgée de 64 ans, mariée et mère 7 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari avec ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle  au  quartier Somono de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école moderne  pour des raisons sociales, c’est plutôt l’école coranique qu’elle fréquenta mais l’abandonna très tôt pour aider sa mère dans les activités commerciales. 
Après plusieurs années auprès de cette dernière jusqu'à son mariage, elle bénéficie d’une bonne éducation commerciale qui lui permet de mieux se débrouiller dans le petit commerce. Après s’être essayé à beaucoup activités génératrices de revenus, elle décida de faire l’achat vente de pagnes fancy, wax et d’autres habits. 
Elle  mène cette  activité  depuis 7 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Dans le dessein de faire face à la demande clientèle,  elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 36 mois, après avoir fait 4 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel.
 Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter, 40 pièces de pagnes wax et une pièce de bazin riche. Elle s’approvisionne sur place à Ségou et effectue sa vente, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 90 000 FCFA, qui lui permettra de subvenir à certaines de ses charges (habillement, savons et médicaments). 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tata S. is 64 years old, married and the mother of seven children. She lives with her children and her husband in a traditional household in the Somono borough of Segou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She has not attended a modern school for social reasons, but rather a coranic school that she soon quit to help her mother in her commercial activities. Having spent several years at her side until her wedding, she developed a solid commercial background which enabled her to manage small businesses. After trying her hand at several revenue-generating activities, she settled on the trade of pagnes (fancy and wax) and other types of clothing (pagnes are colorful West-African clothing fabrics). She has been in business for seven years and enjoys a solid reputation and a large customer following. In order to meet customer demand, she approached Soro Yiriwaso 36 months ago. After four group loans and one personal loan, all repaid in full, she is now requesting a second personal loan. The loan will be used to buy 40 lengths of pagnes wax and one length of rich bazin (embroidered fabric). She gets her supplies locally in Segou and resells them for cash or credit to both men and women customers. She hopes to attain monthly earnings of 90,000 FCFA, which will enable her to meet some of her needs (clothing, soap and medication). Her ambition is to build herself a dwelling.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy pagnes wax and bazin fabric

loans.name: Lor

texts.en:
Mrs. Lor S. is 30 years old and has been selling fresh vegetables in the local, busy market for years. She sells vegetables that she buys from wholesale suppliers and other farmers.

Lor S. is married to Choun Vun, 34, who uses his own motorbike to pick up passers-by for fees and also helps his wife to deliver vegetables to the market. Unfortunately, his motorcycle breaks down often and the current income he earns has been affected. To help solve this problem, Lor S. has requested a loan for the purpose of replacing the broken motor taxi.

Lor S. and her husband are shown in the photo. They currently live with their three school-aged kids who are dependent on their income.

loans.use: To replace her husband's broken motorcycle

loans.name: Ndayambaje

texts.en:
H. is a carpenter and is married with two children. He owns two machines which allow him to make timber for sale. He has been in this business for about fifteen years and the hours of his business are from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

With these fifteen years of experience in his business, the number of H.’s customers has increased to the extent that he can not now satisfy his customers. To end this, he would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase an additional machine which will be useful in making many timbers for sale.

With this machine, H. will satisfy the demand of his customers and he will, hopefully, earn more profits. These profits will allow him to continue taking care of his family. In addition, he will keep reinvesting in his business through creating many sources of income and creating more jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: To buy an additional machine for making timber

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene is 31 years old and is married with four children who are between 6 and 10 years old.

Theogene is commonly known in the business of selling a variety of drugs in his pharmacy and he has been in this business for about three years. The hours of his business are from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.
