Theogene is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company which will allow him to expand his pharmacy through purchasing a large quantity of drugs to sell as well as satisfying the demand of his customers.

With this business satisfaction, Theogene will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business for better financial stability. In addition, he will be able to continue to take care of his family.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of drugs for his pharmacy

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice A. sells both local and imported drugs in her pharmacy at Takoradi. She has received a junior high educational background. She is married and has three wonderful children. Her husband is a carpenter.

Beatrice has been selling drugs for quite some time now, supporting her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more drugs to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for her pharmacy

loans.name: Adjouavé Cyriane

texts.en: Adjouavé Cyriane D. is 36 years old. She was born in Benin but now lives in Togo. She has been in business selling cereals for about 10 years. Mme. D. is married with three children. Her husband works in transportation. Mme. D.'s store is situated in the Adidogome Market, next to the Sedok Hotel. With her loan of 500,000 XOF, she will purchase maize, beans, sorghum, and millet. This is her third loan with WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase cereals - corn maize, beans, sorghum, and millet

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan Q. is a housewife and a mother of three sons. Her husband Raed is a Palestinian National Authority employee and the only one who supports the family, so Raed installed a small coop in the backyard of their house and started breeding chicken for sale.

Susan watched her husband's small project working well and she wanted to help him develop it. Susan came to FATEN and took a $1500 loan which her husband Raed will be using to expand his project by buying more chickens and using the whole space of their backyard to breed a larger number of chickens.

Raed appears in the picture above in FATEN's office as Susan is a conservative woman and doesn't like having her picture published online.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and improve a poultry coop

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Донияров Рустам проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 24 года. Холост. Образование среднее. У него дилерский центр, где он предоставляет услугу, т.е. пополняет счет, продает карточки. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Rustam D. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 24 years old, single. He has a secondary education. Rustam has a dealer center, where he provides services, such as adding funds to accounts and selling cards. He has been involved in this business for 3 years. He is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi Y. produces and sells palm kernel oil at Takoradi. She is married to a farmer and lives with her three children. She has no educational background. Esi uses the income she is able to generate from her sales to support her husband in the general upkeep of the home.

Esi will use the loan to purchase more palm kernels to process for her palm kernel oil. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to buy a nut-cracking machine which is going to reduce the time used to crack the nuts.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernels to process into palm kernel oil

loans.name: Enyonam Ejoua

texts.en: Enyonam Ejoua O. is 45 years old. She was born in Lome but now lives in Adidogome. She is a widow with two children. Madame O. has worked selling coal and cereals since 2000. She works from her home. This is her first loan with WAGES. She plans to use the 400,000 XOF she receives to purchase 20 sacks of coal and 18 sacks of maize.

loans.use: To buy coal and cereals

loans.name: Marufjon

texts.en:
A. Marufjon is 43 years old and married with three children. Marufjon has been operating a butcher shop and meat selling business for 10 years. He provides the markets with meat and his family with the necessary food. Marufjon is requesting a loan of 10,000 TJS. Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro-entrepreneur and his experience in this business, Marufjon is qualified to receive this loan. He is counting on your help. Your support will really help him.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Gulchaman

texts.en: H. Gulchaman is 39 years old and comes from a large and humble family. She is married and the loving mother of four children. Her father's hard and demanding character showed her, from the time she was young, the significant value of work, and therefore she has been successful in various activities throughout her life. Now Gulchaman dedicates herself to raising and selling livestock and, with the income she generates, she provides a better quality of life for her children, who are her greatest joy and have become her best friends. Gulchaman asks for a 7,000 Somoni loan in order to buy more young livestock to raise and sell when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life. Let’s support this dedicated mother's proposal. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more young livestock in order to expand her business

loans.name: Barkawu

texts.en:
Monsieur Barkawu K. is 28 years old. At the moment he is unmarried and has no children. His store, Essofa, has been open since 2008.

This is Mr. K.'s first loan with WAGES. He plans to use his 500,000 CFA loan to purchase various products for his store.

loans.use: To purchase various products for his store

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en: Nodira is a devoted mother who struggles day after day to provide the best for her family. Eight years ago she got the idea to start raising cattle to contribute to the family finances, taking advantage of the space she had available on their land for this business. She is engaged in this business together with her husband. Slowly the number of cows increased and, with the increase, her clients started asking for more and more. With an endless list of requests, she has finally decided to increase the number of livestock she keeps and for this reason is requesting a loan. Be an important part of the growth of Nodira’s business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle and calves to expand her business

loans.name: Adzo

texts.en:
Madame Adzo A. is 33 years old and is married with one child. Her husband is a teacher. She runs a boutique selling cloth, ribbons, buttons, and other items with which to make clothes. She has had her store since 2006.

Madame Adzo requests a loan of 450,000 CFA to purchase more buttons, cloth, and other items for her store. This is her third loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth and buttons and other items

loans.name: Kovi

texts.en:
Monsieur Kovi A. is 51 years old and is married with three children. He runs a business selling stationery and school supplies, and providing copying services.

Kovi has been in business since 1996. His store is called Ets Koprodis and is located on Boulevard de 30 Août in Adidogomé. His family helps him run his store.

Kovi requests 500,000 CFA to purchase more stationery and school supplies. This is his third loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more school supplies and stationery for his store

loans.name: Ramón

texts.es:
El Sr. Ramón J.   tiene 49 años, está casado con la Sra Fidencia Gomez desde hace mas de 30 años, con quien tiene 4 hijos, dos de ellos ya están también casados y dos de ellos están viviendo con ellos porque son menores de edad.
El Sr. Ramón hace 15 años que trabaja en la Venta de Medicamentos, como Analgésicos, Calmantes, Des congestivos, Digestivos, Vendas, pañales descartables,  etc. 
Todos estos productos compra en le Mercado Municipal de San Lorenzo.
Una vez que el cuenta con las mercaderías  recorre  los negocios de diferentes barrios  de la ciudad en una moto con acople en donde carga  todos sus mercados. 
Con el crédito actual tiene pensado comprar Medicamentos comúnmente consumidos en esta Época de Inverno donde las Personas están mas  expuestos  a los cambios climáticos de la Temporada de bajas Temperatura.-
texts.en:
Ramón J., 49, has been married to Fidencia Gómez for over 30 years; they have four children, two of whom are themselves married and two still minors living at home with their parents. Ramón has sold medicines like: analgesics, tranquilizers, decongestants, digestion aids, bandages, disposable diapers, etc. for over 15 years; he buys all his products in San Lorenzo’s municipal market. Once he has secured his stock items he drives his motorcycle, which is equipped with an attached cargo bed to carry his wares, through the city’s different neighborhoods. He will use the funds to buy medicines that are of common use during winter when temperatures drop and people are more exposed to weather changes.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted medicines.

loans.name: Angele

texts.en:
Madame Angele T. is 44 years old. She was born in Lomé and now lives in Adidogomé, Togo. She is married with three children and her husband is retired.

Angele has been selling cereals since 1998. She requests 300,000 CFA to purchase more maize, sorghum, and wood. This is her second loan with WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more maize, sorghum, and wood

loans.name: Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Ramón R. esta casado con la señora Silvina Jara  ellos tienen 2 hijos menores  y viven en la casa de sus padres.
Ramón   tiene un pequeño negocio de fabricación de tapa junta de motor, el trabaja con su padre  de quien aprendió  este oficio y  necesita de este crédito para la compra de materia prima en cantidad por los pedidos  que tiene . 
El trabaja con su señora quien recibe los pedidos y también hace las entregas ,mientras Ramón y su padre realizan  los trabajos.
En el futuro desea comprar un vehículo para las entregas  de sus productos y de esa  manera  cumplir mejor con sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ramón R. is married to Silvina Jara and they have two minor children; they live in his parents’ house. Ramón has a small business making metal moldings for vehicle motors; he works with his father who taught him this skill. He needs funds to buy raw materials in quantity to fill his pending orders. He also works with his wife who takes orders and makes deliveries while Ramón and his father manufacture the parts. In the future, he’d like to buy a vehicle to use for deliveries so that he can provide better service to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy metal and paint.

loans.name: Abra

texts.en:
Madame Abra D. is 35 years old and runs a beauty salon in the Amadahome quarter of Adidogomé, Togo. Her husband is a mason and they have three children.

Madame D. runs her salon out of her home and has been open since 2007. She requests a loan of 350,000 CFA to purchase more beauty products. This is her second loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase more beauty products

loans.name: Aminata Aziz

texts.en:
Aminata owns a stall at Victoria Park located in the middle part of the city. She trades in different type of textiles, and other clothes.

Aminata is 49 years of age and has spent eighteen years in business. She is married to a retired pharmacist and has three children: two of them are in junior secondary school with one at primary level.

Aminata is looking for a loan to enable her to acquire additional stock. She intends going to Guinea, a neighboring country, to buy goods in larger quantities and affordable prices, which will enable her to make more profit. She is hoping to open a drugstore for her retired husband with proceeds from the loan.

loans.use: To buy more textiles to sell

loans.name: Sorbeh 1A Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the three members of the Sorbeh IA Group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makump Bana village, located about five miles from Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,200,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Musa S. B. (pictured on the left). He was born in Makump Bana village and is age 36. He is married with five children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending primary schools.

For more than seven years now, Musa has been selling dishes, cottons and T-Shirts. With his share of this loan, he will buy more dishes, cottons and T-Shirts to add to his inventory.

loans.use: To buy more dishes, cottons and T-Shirts to sell

loans.name: Second Hand Clothing Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Second Hand Clothing” group. They are small-scale businessmen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,400,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Joseph M. B., pictured on the left. Joseph is age 40 and was born in Makeni. He is married with 6 children.  For many years now, Joseph has been selling used clothes. With his share of the loan, he will buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory

loans.name: Ol-Tite Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “OL-Tite” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva in order to seek a loan of SLL 1,400,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Unisa K. (pictured left). Unisa was born in Makeni 35 years ago. He is married and has two children. His children are attending primary school. For many years now,  Unisa has been selling T-shirts and jeans, right at the center of Makeni city. He will use his share of the loan to increase his stock of T-shirts and jeans.

loans.use: Buy T-shirts and jeans in large quantity

loans.name: Flamingo Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Flamingo” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Alex K., pictured on the left. Alex is age 46 and was born in Makeni. He is married with 3 children who are attending primary school.  For 8 years now, Alex has been selling medicines. This loan will assist Alex to improve his business as he will use it to buy more drugs to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Buy more medicines to add to his current stock

loans.name: Ta-Kuru Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Ta-Kuru” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Mariatu B. (pictured left) is the leader of this group. The 35-year-old is married and has three children who are attending primary school. Mariatu has been a businesswoman for many years now; she sells cooked bulgur. With her share of this loan, she will buy bulgur wheat and cooking ingredients such as palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, etc. wholesale in order to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy bulgur wheat and cooking ingredients such as palm-oil, etc.

loans.name: Water Side Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will be able to add more stock to their business inventories, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school and feeding and clothing them. 

Marie S. (pictured left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni 45 years ago. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a businessman and some of her children are attending school – two are married and three are in secondary school. 

Marie sells rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil).  She has been doing this business for many years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying rice and palm oil wholesale.

loans.use: Buy rice and palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Kamuyu Iii Group

texts.en:
In the photo are the four members of the “Kamuy III” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Wara K., pictured on the left. She was born in Makeni and is age forty; she is married to a farmer and they have five children: two in secondary school and three in primary school.

Wara has earned six years of experience in selling cooked rice with meat, fish and vegetables. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business; she will buy cooking ingredients like rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), fish, meats, etc., in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy more cooking ingredients in large quantity

loans.name: Go-Befo Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses.

With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will each be able to add more stock to their business, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by feeding and clothing their children and sending them to school. 

Yeakain S. is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni city thirty years ago. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending schools: two in secondary school and the two in primary school.

Yeakain sells cooked cassava and she has been doing this for many years now. With her share of the loan she will buy more cassava and other cooking ingredients in large quantity in order to improve the size and quality of her business.

loans.use: To buy more cassava and other cooking ingredients in large quantity

loans.name: A And J Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the “A and J” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni.

This is not the first loan that these entrepreneurs have accessed a loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of previous loans, they have been able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their living conditions. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again seeking a new loan in order to further strengthen their businesses.

Jariatu J. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Sanda village. She is about 35 years of age, married to a businessman, and they have four children who are attending both primary and secondary schools.

Jariatu owns a shop on Makeni’s busiest road where she sells a wide variety of commodities including milk, sugar, butter, margarine, mayonnaise, batteries, soaps, Vaseline, and many other different items. She has been a businesswoman for many years now.

With her share of this loan, Jariatu will buy more of the above mentioned items in wholesale to add to her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more items wholesale to add to her inventory

loans.name: Hands Together Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the “Hands Together” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the city of Makeni. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan.

With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and make better profits. Consequently, their living standards will improve and they will be able to at least provide three meals a day for their children, pay their schools fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills if any of them become sick.

Hawa F. is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni and is 30 years of age. She is married to a businessman, and they have two children.

Hawa sells market-food – palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), pepper, salt, rice, etc. – and has been doing this for many years now. With the help of this loan, she will buy more palm-oil, pepper, salt and rice in large quantities to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy more palm-oil, pepper, salt and rice in large quantities

loans.name: Adama

texts.en: Adama K. trades in African art works, Her business is located at the central business district in the capital city of Sierra Leone.  She is 41 years old and has spent 20 years in business. She is married to Lamin Kargbo who makes his living driving in the city.  They have  two children, one of whom is now in senior secondary school. Adama has five other dependents who live with her. She is very determined to succeed in business and is looking for a loan to buy more goods to meet the growing needs of her customers. She hopes to use the proceeds from the loan to set up a business for her husband.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Donatien

texts.en:
Donatien is 33 years old and is still single. He is well known for the business of selling a variety of goods as the photo indicates. He has been in this business for about two years. The hours of his business are from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day.

Donatien is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing additional goods such as rice, sugar, corn flour, etc. With these additional goods for sale, he will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business and start saving for the future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for his store

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en: Nulu is a single mother of four children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Nulu owns a stall in Ndeeba market selling bananas. She doesn’t incur any transport costs because she buys from her place of work.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She has been doing this business for over 18 years. She pays monthly market dues. Nulu sells at retail and at wholesale. Nulu works seven days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of bananas.  Nulu has been with MCDT for seven and half years servicing her 20th loan. Her goals and aspirations are to educate her children up to university and to start going directly to farmers for her bananas. She joined MCDT because of being honest and transparent in loan appraisals. Nulu lives in a three-room house where she stays with eight people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and market dues.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 38 years and single. She is the mother of three children aged between sixteen and one and a half years. She runs a cafeteria in Nairobi. She has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy sugar, rice, beans, baking powder, maize flour and wheat flour to make the food for her cafeteria. Mary dreams of expanding her business, opening more outlets, and growing it into a hotel. Her loan is guaranteed by her group members.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, beans, baking powder, maize flour and wheat flour

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kodjo Mensah

texts.en: Monsieur Kodjo Mensah I. is 33 years old and married with two children. His wife sells cereals. Monsieur Mensah runs a photocopying service in the Gblinkome quarter of Adidogome. He has been running his business since 2007. He requests a loan of 500,000 CFA to purchase a photocopier machine. This is his second loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase a photocopier

loans.name: Ñepytyvo Rekavo Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Ciudad de Villa Hayes Chaco.
Actualmente se encuentran en el segundo ciclo, en su mayoría  de las clientes se dedican a la  ventas.
Todas las señoras con mucho esfuerzo y  responsabilidad ven el fruto de su trabajo  que con mucho esfuerzo lograron.
Una de las señoras es Doña María quien se dedica a la criá y engorde de cerdos.
En ocasiones ella compra cerdos para engorde y en otras directamente los compra para el faenado y venta, esto pasa cuando tiene muchos pedidos.
Solicita el préstamo  para la compra de balanceados para engorde actualmente tiene algunos cerdos que están requiriendo de mucha alimentación para su terminación para la venta.
texts.en:
The Enterprising Women of Ciudad de Villa Hayes Chaco committee is in its second cycle; most of the members are in retail. All of the women see the fruits of their labor which they reaped with much responsibility and effort. One of them is María who is a pig farmer. Sometimes she buys pigs to raise and sometimes directly to slaughter for sale; the latter happens when she has a lot of orders to fill. She is asking for funds to buy nutritionally balanced feed because she has a few pigs that need a lot of nutrition to reach sale weight.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nutritionally balanced pig feed.

loans.name: Prosscovia

texts.en: Prosscovia is married with two children who go to school.  She also takes care of her old mother. She resides in and owns a three-room house. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Prosscovia owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling second hand clothes. She sells to all categories of people. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Prosscovia has been in this business for seven years. She works seven days a week. Prosscovia buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city and uses public transport to and from shopping. Prosscovia goes shopping every Monday.  She incurs transport costs to and from shopping.  Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters. She aspires to go directly to Mombasa for clothes.  She joined MCDT because she wanted to get additional capital for her business. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Afua Enyonena Ehia

texts.en: Afua Enyonena Ehia Amozou sells beauty products in Adidogome, Togo. Her business has been open since 2002. She sells different kinds of beauty products and goods out of her home. She is married with two children. Her husband is an employee of Ecobank. She requests 200,000 CFA to purchase beauty products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products

loans.name: C5260 Hope Group

texts.en:
Angelique is 40 years old and is married with five children who are aged between 3 and 16. She also takes care of one dependent from her family.

Angelique’s business is to sell a variety of clothes; her business is famous as well as organized. She describes herself as a hardworking woman in her daily activities. Her business is open from 8 in the morning to 5 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Angelique is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business through purchasing more bales of clothes. This purchase will allow her to serve more customers from the community which will help her to earn more money.

The profits Angelique expects to earn will be one of the ways she will develop her business and will provide all the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes to grow her business

loans.name: La Santa Cruz Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama LA SANTA CRUZ, es un grupo familiar. Le pusieron este nombre ya que son originarios de la comunidad “Ranchería La Cruz” de Nacajuca, Tabasco y en ella festejan esta celebración. Son 3 integrantes en el grupo: la señora Vidalia J. O., representante y Cástulo H. G. (esposos), que se dedican a la venta de frutas y verduras  y  la señora María Santos V. S. que vende zapatos por catálogo.

El matrimonio de doña Vidalia y don Castulo se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras, en ello invirtieron su crédito. Tienen su establecimiento en el mercado Pino Suárez ubicado en Villahermosa, capital del Estado y en su domicilio también venden productos en el corredor de su casa. Tienen tres hijos que están estudiando primaria y secundaria.
 
Su sueño a largo plazo es llegar a tener una frutería bien surtida que le permita emplear a su familia y les genere un ingreso fijo y sea un negocio autosuficiente para darles estudios a sus hijos.

Ellos se sienten motivados y agradecidos por que através del crédito otorgado por  Fundación Realidad y KIVA su negocio se va encaminando para lograr sus sueños.
texts.en:
This group is called LA SANTA CRUZ, a family group. They chose this name because they’re natives of the community, “Ranchería La Cruz,” in Nacajuca, Tabasco where they celebrate this festival. There are 3 members of the group, Vidalia J. O. and Cástulo H. G. (married), who sell fruit and vegetables, and María Santos V. S. who sells shoes by catalog.

The married pair, doña Vidalia y don Castulo, sell fruits and vegetables and will invest their loan in this. They have their stall in the Pino Suárez market, located in Villahermosa, capital of the state. They also sell products in their home from the entryway of their house. They have three children that are studying in secondary and primary schools.

Their long-term dream is to have a well-stocked fruit shop that will allow them to employ their family and have a steady income. It would be a self-sufficient business that could pay their children’s tuition. They are motivated and thankful, because thanks to the loan granted by Kiva and Fundación Realidad, their business is moving to meet their dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vegetables and fruit, tomatoes, onions, yucca, pumpkins, shoes

loans.name: Loise

texts.en: Loise operates a general merchandise shop in Nairobi where she sells music and video cassettes and tapes as well as household products and utensils. She previously sold electronics and clothes until 1998 when she began her current business. She has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to her inventory of music and video tapes and household items. She is a member of Yes We Can Self Help Group whose members guarantee each other’s loans. A mother of three children aged between twelve and one and a half years, Loise hopes to provide a comfortable life for her children and buy a house. She describes herself as hard working.

loans.use: To add inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mujeres Hacia El Progreso(Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Mujeres Hacia el Progreso está formado por siete  socias que siempre se encuentran en la búsqueda de mejores días para sus familias y así poder brindarles  un mejor presente y futuro; todas las socias viven en la urbe de la  ciudad de Cuenca, esta hermosa ciudad del Ecuador tiene para el turista nacional y extranjero hermosos paisajes naturales y la belleza de su centro histórico donde se encuentran  importantes vestigios históricos como el  museo y la  Catedral de la Inmaculada Concepción  una de las más grandes y hermosas de América y otras más que datan de los siglos XVI y XVII. Sus  calles adoquinadas y casas con fachadas de estilo republicano hacen notar las diferentes influencias europeas con nobles balcones y cielorrasos tallados artísticamente. La ciudad es además conocida como la "Cuenca de los Andes" o la "Atenas del Ecuador" por ser cuna de poetas y hombres ilustres que han dejado en alto el nombre de esta ciudad.
En esta ocasión nos acompaña el señor Eulogio Rojas coordinador de la regional Azuay junto a las socias del banco comunal Mujeres hacia el Progreso.

La  señora  Jennifer García vive en el centro de la Ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 26 años de edad se encuentra casada y ha concebido un hijo que se encuentra de dos años, su esposo es diseñador  grafico en la  imprenta de su suegro de la que se hizo cargo hace ocho años, al momento no tienen casa propia viven compartiendo con sus suegros la casa y los gastos que en ella se genera. Jennifer  trabaja también en la imprenta prestando sus servicios profesionales como contadora hace tres años laborando de  8 a.m. a 1 p.m. dedicándose el resto del tiempo a su hijo.

Se encuentra trabajando con los préstamos del bankito ya tres años gracias a que fue invitada  por su mamá a  formar parte de este hermoso grupo de mujeres emprendedoras, los crédito le han beneficiado en los gastos de su hogar y en la imprenta de su esposo, con su nuevo crédito va adquirir  una impresora para su negocio.

Su meta es llegar a tener una casa propia.

Flora tiene 63 años de edad y vive con su esposo abogado de profesión en su casa propia gracias al esfuerzo conyugal, tiene tres hijos de 35, 32, 30 años que son casados y viven independientes
>p>
La  señora  Flora Campo trabaja hace ocho  años en el bankito y fue invitada por una compañera del gremio de artesanos  ya que ella es costurera de  oficio hace cincuenta años,  labor que aprendió de su madre,  tiene un pequeño taller en su casa donde  trabaja según los pedidos que tiene que entregar y labora de lunes a sábados sin un horario establecido. Con su nuevo credito va a comprar telas, hilos, botones, cierres, gafetes, etc.  para abastecer su taller de costura.

Su sueño es ver a todos sus hijos tener su casa propia para tranquilidad de toda la familia.
texts.en:
The Women for Progress Communal Bank consists of seven members who are constantly striving for better days for their families, to offer them a better present and future. All members live in the Cuenca area. For both domestic and foreign tourists, this beautiful Ecuadorian city offers gorgeous natural scenery and the beauty of its historic center, home to historic remains such as the museum and Immaculate Conception Cathedral, one of the largest and most beautiful in America, as well as others dating back to the 16th and 17th centuries. Its cobblestone streets and houses with facades typical of the republican era give witness to the different European influences, with noble balconies and artistic ceilings. The city is also known as the “Valley of the Andes,” or the “Athens of Ecuador,” because it is the cradle of illustrious men and poets, who have made the city famous. For this occasion we are joined by Eulogio Rojas, coordinator of the Azuay regional area, along with members of the Women for Progress Communal Bank. Jennifer G. lives in downtown Cuenca, is 26 years old, married, and has a two-year-old child. Her husband is a graphics designer in his father-in-law’s printing house, who took this over eight years ago. They do not have their own home at this time, but share a house with their in-laws, along with its expenses. Jennifer also works in the printing house, providing professional services in the accounting area, for three years now working from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., with the rest of her time devoted to her child. She has been working with loans from this bank for three years now, thanks to her mother’s invitation to join this lovely group of enterprising women. The loans have served her for household expenses and for her husband’s printing house. Her next loan will go to purchase a printing press for the business. Her goal is to have her own home. Flora is 63 years old, and lives with her lawyer husband in her own home, achieved through their own efforts. They have three children, 35, 32, and 30 years of age, who are married and independent. For eight years, Flora Campo has worked in the bank, being invited by a colleague from the artisans’ union, as she has been a seamstress by trade for fifty years, which she learned from her mother. She has a small shop in her home, where she fulfills orders, working from Monday to Saturday on a schedule that varies. With her next loan, she will buy fabric, thread, buttons, zippers, clasps, etc., to supply her workshop. Her dream is to see all of her children in their own homes, which will bring comfort to the family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a printing press, and fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, clasps, etc.

loans.name: Ataa

texts.en:
Ataa P. is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. She has received no form of education. She produces palm kernel oil for distribution at Takoradi and uses her earnings to help sustain the home.

Ataa will use the loan to obtain more palm fruits to process to produce more palm kernel oil to sell. With the increased sales from her extended business, she plans to plow back her profit.

loans.use: To buy more palm fruits to process into palm kernel oil

loans.name: Agustina

texts.es:
Ña Agustina tiene 58 años, está casada y tiene 2 hijos que también emplean sus esfuerzos en la actividad de sus padres. 
Se dedica en el alquiler de sillas, mesas, manteles, vajillas, cubiertos, salón, para eventos sociales como cumpleaños infantiles, quince años, reuniones de todo tipo etc., hace mas 10 años que esta en esta actividad.
Con los préstamos que obtuvo de la Fundación Paraguaya pudo renovar los manteles y una parte de las vajillas, manteniendo en forma se muestran atractivos y presentables toda su decoración y ampliar así su demanda.
texts.en:
Doña Agustina is 58 years old, married, and has two children who help with her business. She manages a rental business where she provides chairs, tables, tablecloths, dishes, cutlery, and a location for social events such as children’s birthday parties, quinceañeras, reunions, and other occasions. Agustina has been in business for more than ten years.

With this loan from Fundación Paraguaya, she will be able to replace her tablecloths and some of her dishes because it is important to maintain an attractive and presentable setting so that she can increase demand for her service.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tablecloths & dishes

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with eight children and five of her children go to school.  She lives in a rented two-room house.  Rose doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She owns a retail shop in Kamwokya Kifumbira. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of soap, cartons of salt, bags of rice, beans, trays of eggs and cakes.  She has been in this business for many years.  Besides this business, she also owns eight rental rooms in the village.  Her major customers are community members. She works seven days a week.   Her business challenges are increase in prices of merchandise and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala city to her shop in Kamwokya.  She aspires to buy iron sheets to complete her unfinished house. Rose joined MCDT because of their methodology and because of school fees loans.  Her monthly expenses include food, school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To  buy more sugar, soap, salt, eggs and beans

loans.name: Montserrat Group

texts.es:
El grupo “Montserrat”,  nombrado así por que el día de la solicitud se celebraba nuestra Señora de Montserrat, esta integrado por cinco mujeres. Las representa doña Esperanza M. H., ella tiene 1 hija. Doña Esperanza se dedica a la venta de zapatos marca B Hermanos para damas, caballeros y niños realizando sus pedidos en la ciudad de Villahermosa. Doña Trinidad tiene 6 hijos, tiene  una herrería junto con su esposo, esta ubicada a lado de su casa, doña Yolanda tiene 2 hijos, su negocio es una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su domicilio, doña  Luvia y doña Natividad tienen 2 hijas cada una y  se dedican  a la venta de pollos, que crían en sus respectivos domicilios. 

Doña Trina, como la conocen en su comunidad, comprará más materiales como ángulos, tubulares, fierros, láminas para hacer los pedidos que le solicitan como puertas, ventanas, portones, protecciones. Su Esposo y ella, sueñan con tener un taller de herrería más completo para satisfacer mejor las necesidades de sus clientes y que sus hijos puedan estudiar una carrera universitaria.

Son mujeres  muy trabajadoras  y sus actividades son diferentes, es un grupo solidario y se conocen desde hace años.  

Agradecen el apoyo que le brinda la Fundación y KIVA por considerarlos para poder realizar sus pequeños negocios.
texts.en:
The Montserrat Group is aptly named because the day of their loan request occurred during the celebration for Our Lady of Montserrat. The group consists of five women and is led by Doña Esperanza M. H., who has a daughter. Doña Esperanza sells brand name shoes from “B Hermanos” (a Mexican shoe store chain) for women, men, and children. She fulfills her orders in the city of Villahermosa.

Doña Trinidad has six children and operates a blacksmith shop with her husband. The business is located beside their house. Doña Trina, as she is known in the community, will buy more materials such as angle iron, tubing, scrap iron, and metal sheeting so that she can complete orders she receives for doors, window frames, gates, and privacy shields. She and her husband dream of having a blacksmith shop that is complete so that they can better satisfy the needs of their customers. They also hope that their children will be able to study for their university degree.

Doña Yolanda has two children and manages a grocery store in her home. Doña Luvia and Doña Natividad have two daughters each. Both women sell chickens that they raise at home.

All of these women work extremely hard in their different businesses. They are a close-knit group and have known each other for many years. The group would like to thank the Foundation and Kiva for their support and consideration which will allow them to continue their small businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase blacksmithing materials

loans.name: Rabbeca

texts.en: Rabbeca is 24, married, and has been in business for two years. She sells household products such as sufurias (cooking pots), spoons, buckets and cups. She has requested for a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to her inventory. She has begun saving since she joined Faulu Kenya Limited and hopes to own a wholesale shop in the future. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To add inventory

loans.name: Yuri Jannet

texts.es:
Yuri es una madre de familia de 29 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus dos hijos de 9 y 4 años de edad en el distrito de Monsefú, conocido en el norte por la elaboración de artesanías en arcilla y madera y también por sus actividades turístico religiosas, se encuentra ubicado a veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de tres años a la vena de abarrotes y golosinas en una pequeña bodega – tienda instalada en su domicilio. El negocio le brinda algunas ganancias que utiliza en ayudar a su esposo con el sustento de la economía familiar. Su negocio goza de muy buena demanda, ya que ella trata siempre de brindar productos de calidad y un buen trato a sus clientes.

Durante los ultimos meses su negocio ha estado experimentando una creciente demanda por lo que Yuri está ampliando poco a poco su negocio con la compra de mas productos, para ayudarse a lograr su objetivo ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

Yuri es una madre que da lo mejor de si para sacar adelante a su familia. Ella es considerada por sus vecinos y clientes como una mujer trabajadora y bastante colaboradora. Anteriormente ya ha trabajado con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Yuri is a 29 year old mother who lives with her husband and two children (ages 9 and 4) in the District of Monsefú. This area is known in the north for its production of clay and wooden handicrafts, as well as its religious activities for tourists. The district is located twenty minutes away from the city of Chiclayo.

For more than three years, Yuri has been selling groceries and candy from a small store located inside her home. The business provides some income so that she can help her husband manage the family expenses. Her business is in high demand since she always tries to provide high quality products and good service to her customers.

Within the past few months, Yuri has been experiencing increased demand so she wants to gradually expand her business by purchasing more products. To meet this goal, she is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 500 PEN.

Yuri is a mother who wants to provide the best for her family so that they can succeed. She is considered by her neighbors and customers to be a hardworking and cooperative woman. Yuri has previously worked with Edpyme Alternativa and demonstrated that she is punctual and responsible when submitting her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is 23 and runs a retail shop in Nairobi. She has been in this business for two years. She was previously employed in a pharmacy. She has requested for a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to her stock of sugar, rice and flour for her business. Ruth is a member of Joy Partners Self Help Group and the members of the group have guaranteed her loan. She wants to own residential and commercial houses in the future. She plans to grow her business to a supermarket in five years. She describes herself as hard working.

loans.use: To add to her stock of sugar, rice and flour

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eveneser Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama Evenecer, que significa “Hasta Aquí dios te ayudo”. Está ubicado en el Estado D.  México.  El grupo está conformado por 10 integrantes.
Brisa Elena R. Jiménez es el la presidenta  D. grupo. Tiene 19 años, estudió hasta el 1  año D. preparatoria, es comerciante D. Resina y no tiene  hijos.  Ella se dedica a realizar figuras D. resina que inició hace 2 años. Solicita el préstamo para comprar material y poder realizar sus figuras. Sus clientes algunos son turistas y otros son personas D. la república a las que les lleva sus figuras.  Al momento D. solicitar este préstamo se siente contenta. Quiere este crédito invertir en material.   También espera ir comprando poco a poco muebles para su casa.
Los otros integrantes D. grupo son:
-F. M. MICAELINA MOLINO
-G. M. REBECA               VENTA D. ZAPATOS POR CATALOGO
-D. R. M. NOEMI               VENTA D. ROPA
-H. M. ANCELMA ALEJANDRA VENTA D. RECINA
-T. G. LUZ MARIA              VENTA D. TORTILLAS
-H. V. JUANA              VENTA D. RECINA
-A. G. TRINIDAD                VENTA D. PERFUMES
-M. MORALES MARIA LEONOR        VENTA D. TAPETES
-H. G. CONSTANTINA         VENTA D. CERAMICA.
texts.en:
This group is called Evenecer, which means God helped you so far. The group is in Mexico, and it is comprised of ten members. Brisa Elena R. Jiménez is the president of the group. She is 19, and she went to school up to her first year in high school. She is a resin merchant, and she has no children. She makes figures from resin; she started two years ago. She is requesting a loan to buy material to be able to make her figures. Some of her customers are tourists, and others are from the republic where she takes the figures. She is happy at the time she requests the loan. She wants the loan to buy material. She also plans to, little by little, buy furniture for her house. The other members of the group are: - M. Micaelina: Food mill - G. M. Rebeca: Sells shoes by catalog - D. R. M. Noemí: Sells clothes - H. M. Ancelma Alejandra: Sells resin - T. G. Luz Maria: Sells tortillas - H. V. Juana: Sells resin - A. G. Trinidad: Sells perfume - M. Morales Maria Leonor: Sells mats - H. G. Constantina: Sells ceramics

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material

loans.name: Mujeres Activas De Candia Loma Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son de la Compañía Candia Loma de la cuidad de Caacupé distante a 6 km de la oficina regional Caacupé.
Con el apoyo financiero que la fundación Paraguaya les brinda hoy por hoy, las integrantes se sienten seguras trabajando en sus propios negocios, lo que comercialmente realizan les ayudan al sustento familiar, para sus respectivos negocios necesitan de una previa y buena planificación.
El negocio de la señora Petrona es una despensa que cuenta con todos los artículos necesarios para la casa.
Ella es una señora muy trabajadora que lleva adelante a su familia de la mejor manera posible y ayuda de cualquier modo a su marido quien no posee un ingreso fijo ya que se dedica a venta artesanía.
Ella tiene algunos gastos personales con sus hijos y también debe volver a cargar su despensa con las mercaderías que fueron vendidas por ello solicita el préstamo para la compra de panificados, enlatados, embutidos, fideos, arroz, harina.   

A esta fecha todas  las integrantes operan con la fundación paraguaya en el ciclo número 8 del programa comité de mujeres emprendedoras, emprendiendo cada día proyectos de mejoramiento y desarrollo para personas  de escasos recursos.
texts.en:
The women of this existing committee are from the Candia Loma Assembly in the city of Caacupé, which is 6km from the Caacupé regional office. With the financial support they receive from Fundación Paraguaya, the members feel secure working in their own businesses because they are able to plan ahead and provide for their families.

Sra. Petrona manages a store where she sells all types of items needed for the home. She is a hardworking woman who gets ahead on behalf of her family in the best way possible. Her husband sells handicrafts, but since he does not earn a steady income, she tries to help in any way she can. Petrona has a few personal expenses related to her children and she also wants to restock her store with merchandise that is low in supply. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy baked goods, canned goods, sausages, noodles, rice, and flour.

As of now, all of the members are participating in their eighth loan cycle in the Committee of Women Entrepreneurs Program with Fundación Paraguaya, which establishes daily improvement projects and promotes the development of individuals with limited resources.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase baked goods, canned goods, sausages, noodles, rice, and flour

loans.name: Roberta

texts.es: Roberta tiene 55 años, comparte su vida con su esposo Jesús D. 60 años y sus 4 hijos, quienes ya son mayores D. edad e independientes económicamente, pero viven juntos en su casa que es propia, ubicado en la ciudad D. Pichanaki. Sus campos agrícolas producen todo los productos naturales oriundos D. la zona, por eso lo cuida con mucho esmero desD. hace 15 años. Paralelamente a esta actividad, también se dedica a la fabricación D. ladrillos, esto lo realiza en compañía D. su esposo.  Ambos disfrutan D. sus trabajos y lo gratificante que le resulta, permitiéndoles vivir cómodamente. Lo que más le gusta D. la agricultura es procurar que estén limpios sus terrenos, D. esa manera se desarrollaran mejor, sin embargo el tener que trasladar su cosecha a los puntos D. venta, siempre le ha sido muy pesado y caro por tener que pagar el flete. Su carácter emprendedor le ha dado mucha ventaja para continuar trabajando, por lo que ahora anhela instalar un negocio D. venta D. comestibles al por mayor y menor en su vivienda y con ello lograr a ser una D. las distribuidoras más importantes D. su localidad. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP y como ya conoce la metodología D. trabajo D. su grupo comunal se muestra contenta D. seguir perteneciendo a este grupo que es muy unido y exigente en los pagos, eso le convierte en una persona responsable. Con el crédito que solicita, contratará operarios para que retiren la maleza D. sus terrenos así como comprar insecticidas para cuidar D. las plagas que afecten sus plantaciones.
texts.en:
Roberta is 55 years old and shares her life with her husband Jesús, who is 60 years old, and their four adult children. Even though they are financially independent, her children still live in her house located in the city of Pichanaki. Her farmland produces all types of natural products that are indigenous to the area. Roberta has been farming with great care for the past 15 years. In addition, she manufactures bricks along with her husband. They both enjoy the work and find it rewarding since it allow them to live comfortably. What she enjoys most about farming is clearing her land because it allows her crops the best chance to develop properly. However, transporting her harvest to market is difficult because the loads are heavy and the cost of moving the freight is expensive. Her entrepreneurial spirit has proven to be an advantage because it has enabled her to continue working. Roberta now yearns to open a grocery store in her home where she can sell retail and wholesale with hopes of becoming one of the largest distributors in the area.

This is her fourth loan with MFP. Roberta is familiar with the work methodology of her Communal Bank and happy to continue her membership because her group is very close and demanding when it comes to completing their payments. As a result, Roberta has become a responsible person. With the loan she requested, Roberta will hire workers to rid her farmland of weeds. She will also buy insecticides to guard against pests that can impact her crops.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase insecticides & hire workers to remove weeds from her land

loans.name: Segundo Baltazar

texts.es:
Segundo tiene 65 años de edad, es casado y tiene tres hijos, vive con su esposa y el ultimo de sus hijos en el sector Carlos Stein del distrito de José Leonardo Ortiz, un distrito próximo a la ciudad de Chiclayo considerado el distrito mas poblado de la región, pero también el que presenta mayores indices de pobreza.

Se dedica desde hace mas de un año a la venta de frutas y golosinas en un pequeño puesto ambulante ubicado frente al terminal terrestre de la ciudad de Chiclayo, el negocio cuenta con muy buena acogida ya que la zona diariamente es frecuentada por bastantes personas que viajan hacia pueblos del interior de la región. El le dedica todo el dia a esta actividad y con las ganancias que percibe solventa los gastos familiares.

Segundo desea implementar su negocio con la compra de más fruta, ya que este es el producto que goza de mayor demanda en su negocio, para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por pirmera vez a Edyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

Segundo es una persona trabajadora y que siempre ha velado por el progreso y bienestar de los suyos, sus compañeros de trabajo y vecinos coinciden en que el es alguien honrado, responsable y que siempre está dispuesto a ayudar a los que le necesitan.
texts.en:
Segundo is 65 years old, married, and has three children. He lives with his wife and their youngest child in the Carlos Stein sector of the District of José Leonardo Ortiz, which lies next to the city of Chiclayo. This district is considered to be the most populous in the region and also has the highest poverty rates.

For more than a year, Segundo has been selling fruits and candy from a small street stand located in front of a bus terminal in the city of Chiclayo. His business has been well-received and is frequented daily by many people traveling to the inland towns of the region. He spends all day at his business and uses his earnings to cover his family’s expenses.

Segundo wants to continue his business by purchasing more fruit since there is high demand for this product. In order to do this, he is requesting his first loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 500 PEN.

Segundo is a hardworking individual who always looks out for the progress and welfare of his family. His coworkers and neighbors consider him to be someone who is honest, responsible, and always willing to help when needed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruit

loans.name: Jacqueline Elizabeth

texts.es:
Jacqueline de 39 años, vive en una zona urbana en el Guasmo de Guayaquil, su esposo trabaja en una empresa de seguridad, ellos tienen tres hijos, empezó como microempresaria con una tienda hace un año atrás, con el fin de ayudar con los gastos familiares y darle una mejor vida a sus hijos. 

Empezó readecuando la sala de su casa y convirtiéndola en un local pequeño para su tienda, compro víveres y papelería para su negocio. Por esa buena decisión ahora ella tiene una tienda mixta con víveres y papelería, trabaja desde las 07h00 hasta las 19h00 todos los días. Quiere que su tienda este mas surtida por lo que con el préstamo quiere comprar vitrinas, laminas y víveres para su tienda. 

En el futuro quiere agrandar su tienda y tener sucursales.
texts.en:
Jacqueline is 39 years old and lives in the urban area of Guasmo in Guayaquil. Her husband works for a security company. They have three children. Jacqueline started her business one year ago so that she could contribute toward the family expenses and provide her children with a better life.

She remodeled the living room of her house and converted it into a small space for her business. This turned out to be a good decision because she now has a general store that offers both groceries and stationery. She works from 7am until 7pm every day. Jacqueline wants her store to be well-stocked, so she will use her loan to buy display cases, printing supplies, and groceries for her store.

In the future, she wants to expand her store and open branches.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase display cases, printing supplies, and groceries

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Né vers 1960 à San, Djeneba K. n’as pas eu la chance d’ aller à l’école, elle s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus, elle est mariée et mère de 13 enfants. Elle  vit chez son époux dans le quartier Santoro I de la préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Elle a commencé le commerce de poisson fumé avec son mari il y a plus de 20 ans  et l’exerce actuellement pour elle même au grand marché  de San et dans les foires environnantes. 
Elle est très sollicitée dans  des foires hebdomadaires, de San  ville et environnants.  
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, elle décida de faire recours à l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui elle est à son deuxième  prêt individuel, après avoir correctement remboursé le précédent. 
Madame Djeneba compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 40 cartons de poissons fumés à Mopti et payer les frais de transport pour son acheminement  à son magasin situé au  grand marché de San. 
Elle a une clientèle composé de femmes et d’hommes et vend, en détail,  à crédit et au comptant. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 160 000FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et utiliser  le reste pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, acheter la nourriture et investir le reste dans d’autres activités de revenus .
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in San, Djeneba K. did not have the opportunity to attend school, but became quickly interested in revenue-generating activities. She is married and the mother of 13 children. She lives with her husband in the Santoro I borough of the San Prefecture (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She started selling smoked fish with her husband over 20 years ago, and currently runs her own fish-selling business at San’s main market and at other market fairs in the area. In order to satisfy increasing customer demand, she decided to call upon the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, where she is requesting a second personal loan, having correctly reimbursed the first one. Mrs. Djeneba wants to use her loan to buy 40 crates of smoked fish in Mopti, and also pay the transportation costs to her store located at San’s main marketplace. Her customers are both men and women and she sells retail, for cash or credit. She hopes to attain monthly earnings of 160,000 FCFA she will use to reimburse the loan, and use the remainder to pay her children’s tuition fees, buy food, and invest in other revenue-generating activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy smoked fish

loans.name: Bena

texts.en:
Bena is 36 years old and is married with two children who are 7 and 11 years old. She works hard for the development of her family.

Bena owns a small shop selling various products such as shoes, notebooks, cosmetics products, and so on. She has an experience of two years in her business. The hours of her shop are from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Bena is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Company in order to purchase more products for her shop. This expansion will allow her to earn more money to be used in her business and for other family problems.

With the extra income, Bena expects to save some money.

loans.use: To purchase more products for her shop to expand her business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy Z. bakes various kinds of bread and pastries at Takoradi.  Lucy attended a commercial school where she acquired the skills of baking and cooking both local and continental dishes.  She is married and has three beautiful children. Her husband works with the gold mines. Lucy has been baking for some time now. She helps her husband pay for school fees and utility bills. Her loan will enable her to buy more ingredients so she can bake more products to meet the demands of her increasing number of customers. She wishes to use the new profits from her business to help in the payment of the water bills and other expenses.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Gaston Koffi

texts.fr: ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de CD, clé USB et divers consommables informatiques. il s'approvisionne à Lomé, sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. il veut gonfler son stock de marchandises raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 600 CD-ROM, 400 CD (DVD) et 35 clés USB. il est célibataire et c'est avec le revenu de son commerce qu'il subvient à ses propres charges.
texts.en:
This man makes his living by selling CD’s, flash drives and other computer related items. He gets his supplies in Lomé and has a very diverse clientele. He wants to increase his stock of merchandise which is why he is requesting a loan to purchase 600 CD-ROMs, 400 CD’s and DVD’s and 35 flash drives. He is single and with the revenue from his business he is able to make ends meet.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy CD's DVD's and flash drives

loans.name: Gender Workers Group

texts.en:
Dominic C. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Gender Workers. He is 30 years old, single, and has a 3 month old child. He also cares for 6 dependents. He is a college student.

For 7 years, Dominic has been selling provisional goods such as milk, sugar, sardines, cheese, corned beef and soap in a shop at the Bernard Farm community market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. He provides good service to his customers and always makes goods available for them. This keeps customers returning.

Dominic started selling with little cash that he managed to raise from his vacation job. He plans to use his 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more provisional goods such as milk, sugar, sardines, cheese, corned beef and soap. His goal is to improve his family's living conditions.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Dominic is holding the sign. Rejoice N. is inset because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more provisional goods such as milk, sugar, sardines, cheese, corned beef and soap.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
El señor Daniel D. G. tiene ya más de un año con su negocio de taller de herrería. Le está haciendo falta el techo en el patio ya que es donde el realiza sus trabajos, con el sol y las lluvias no a podido terminar los pedidos que tiene pendiente, porque nada mas trabaja por la mañana, decidió construir un techo de lamina y madera y así lo pueda proteger del sol y la lluvias mientras este trabajando.
Solicita el préstamo para poder comprar el material ya que el se encargara de realizar la mejora. Planea pagar el crédito con una parte de las ganancias que obtiene de sus trabajos de herrería, ya que el negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia.
texts.en:
Sr. Daniel D. G. has been operating his blacksmith business for more than a year. He needs to build a roof over his patio since that is where he performs his work. Due to the sun and the rain, he is not able to finish his outstanding orders and can only work in the morning. He decided to install a roof made of tin and wood so that he can be protected from the sun and the rain while he is working. Dante is requesting a loan so that he can buy the necessary materials to complete this improvement. He plans to repay the loan using part of the earnings from his blacksmith business, which is the source of income for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to build a roof over his work area
